content:
Posted: March 10
 UPDATED 05/04/17 I also have to praise CA for the building system, which I personally find to be a more interesting and barely any more restricting mechanic compared to M2TW's. It makes you wonder why it was discarded for the streamlined and pathetic new building slot crap they came up with for Rome 2 and Attila... However I particularly appreciated that the player has a lot of freedom upon which bonuses he wants to favour in a certain region, in that many villages are located around each territory and you can select from a variety of building types the tree you'd like to build and develop. It doesn't mean that region X has no farms or no workshops if, for instance, you only build universities in within its boundaries, it only defines that whatever bonus the region is getting is exclusively focused in researching technologies. I find this system very intriguing and stimulating, but then to each man his own. Also do consider that towns have in most cases space for up to 5+ buildings. I have only seen a handful of capitals that allowed for 2-3 buildings, mostly being very small and insignificant provinces.  Intro pertaining Darthmod Let me start by saying I played no vanilla whatsoever, I launched the game once and then immediately set up Darthmod, and yet the features I found most astonishing and pleasant compared to other Total War instalments are unrelated to the improvements Darthmod applied. However, if what I found to be positive in the game pertains to the vanilla, so do many of the negative points I could of come across in a vanilla game, which were addressed in Darthmod. So, ultimately, indeed my review is not based on the overall quality of the product as downloaded from Steam. Way better than the most recent TW’s Like mentioned above, I consider Empire to be superior to games such as Attila or Rome II, both of which were my very first Total War games (sadly, I didn’t start with the good ol’ ones). Compared to the latter, it seems to have more interesting technologies, meaningful historical events and campaign objectives, as well as an intriguing unit variety. These superior features, so far allowed me to fully enjoy a 50 hours long campaign run, and I’m only at the 45% of it, still fighting and struggling and most importantly enjoying the game. Unlike some most recent TW’s I feel Empire is really rewarding. The technology Tree Before we delve into this, let me assure you I am not discrediting Attila and Rome II because of their theme and period. I am not just a gamer but first and foremost a scholar of the whole medieval period, from 400 to 1450 AD  (there is disagreement among historians regarding the start/end dates). What I love of Attila is in fact the time period, as I know many of the tribes and civilisations included in the game, and I have studied their migrations and customs during the Völkerwanderung. Back to the subject, compared to the stuff we have here, I find Attila’s Tech tree really uninteresting, bland, shallow. I don’t remember a single remarkable upgrade that was stuck in my head as something amazing I couldn’t wait getting my hands on. The opposite feelings I have for Empire’s tree: multiple improvements on bayonet types, on formations, or even new infantry technology (rifles in the mid-late game); then we see through the campaign an exciting development of our and other nations’ artillery, both in the engines themselves and the ammo types too. And that is just the military tree… Which on Attila I find is the most delusional one. The changes and improvements applied by the other two trees are very appealing.  Campaign objectives Short point really. What keeps me going and going on conquering without losing interest for my campaigns is that they match with historical events and conflicts that actually occurred and had an impact on how the world looks now. It’s not just random wandering and slaughtering, which some may like, and I do too, but which gets a tad boring after you run out of fantasy. ETW gives you several possible campaign ‘missions’ as you walk your path to reconstruct a historical empire or something even greater – changing the curse of history. (e.g. Austria winning the 7 years’ war, the British maintaining control over the colonies, etc). I think in this case the fault is not the most recent titles of the Total War franchise are shallow, but that the periods treated in the games are missing some relevant background for several of the factions. Maybe it’s just me, but even sailing to Britannia and making it Englaland with my Saxon spears didn’t feel to rewarding – not as much as defeating the Ottomans with Austria (see the Austro-ottoman wars for further reference). Again, it’s just my feelings and my opinion as for this point, and I can’t blame anyone or anything. Unit variety I have always been concerned by the extent of unit variety in strategy games, and I must say seldom have I been fully satisfied. Empire Total War is one of these very few cases. Playing as Austria, I haven’t a handful of basic units which then upgrade from “generic♥♥♥♥♥♥tier warband” to “mid tier warband” and then further on. I have detailed regiments, which vary depending on the region. I can muster basic line infantry, grenadiers both basic and Hungarian, and the list goes on with line infantry units, first pandurs then grenzers and further on jaegers. (Darthmod mainly adds regional versions of these units, giving some more variety). Of artillery and cavalry units there are many and all work in a different way, although cavalry diversity in Attila was proper enough and siege does not much fit the setting. However as for ETW, I am amazed at the beauty of my army composition, whereas Attila has very bland unit trees for the “barbarian” factions. If I can tell I have been impressed of some units in that game it’s the Lombards’, and unsurprisingly that faction is in a paid DLC. ;)All in all, this is just how I feel about it, and I have no wish to bother putting down numbers and making comparisons as in who has the most units and whose variety and uniqueness is superior between the two games.What I can add is that I’ve seen literally dozens of modders doing the developers’ work on the units Attila, Rome 2 and TW Warhammer contain, whereas even the biggest mods I have come across for Empire added but a handful of units. That’s really all I had to say, hope my review proves useful to someone.Thanks for reading.

												A great game. I'd almost go as far as to say that the replay value is limitless. The tech tree is large and interesting, so are the maps. 												An excellent Total War game that eliminates a lot of the uncessecary micro-management and finally offers some trule co-op multiplayer.The themes, mechanics, and graphics are top-notch however make sure you are running at least a mid-range rig as it is a total resource hog and on lower end machines will be unplayable during battles.For those die-hard fans who enjoyed the micro-management of old and variety of options when creating and managing cities, you may find this game frustrating, especially with how pivotal a role religion plays in this title (realistically in my opinion). number of helpful: 10 of 12 people (83%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 7, 2016
												Bringing the Total War series to the gunpowder age, Empire really nails the "line of battle" style of warfare. It had the biggest map in the series to date, with three massive theaters to conquer and several small trade areas ripe for naval control. Diplomacy was massively overhauled, bringing much-needed improvements and making negotiating actually viable for once. It also introduced several completely new features, including epic playable naval battles and a tech tree to progress through the campaign, both of which have become staples of the series. The historical battles, while great, are less polished than normal and lack the intro cutscenes that are usually featured.There's a mini-campaign included that allows you to play as the USA through four stages of history - Jamestown, French & Indian War, American Revolution, and finally as the USA on the Grand Campaign. It's a special version of the Grand Campaign that starts at 1783 and is incredibly challenging. The biggest downside to the game, by far, is that the DLC unit packs are more or less required to have rosters that feel complete. This was CA's first game to experiment with DLC packs and they left many elite units off of the vanilla rosters, to be included in the DLC. If you get the DLC packs, then the game is amazing, but I fear for the experience of anyone trying to play it vanilla.The Warpath DLC is interesting, but a rather disappointing expansion campaign when compared to the others in the series.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2015
												Empire: Total War is an edition in the Total War series consisting of the titles Rome: Total War, Medieval: Total War 1/2, and many more.  Empire: Total War, if I am not mistaken, is the first Total War game in the series to introduce gunplay in battles along with user controlled naval warfare. I suggest playing the previous installments before jumping into this game.Now let's talk about this game.You start off like most Total War games by selecting who you want your faction to be. Depending on who you choose will place you on a certain part of the map. An addition to this game from the previous installments was that it used more than just Europe and a few surrounds areas. Instead it incorportated parts of Africa and North America. You could travel to the different sections of the world on your power for conquest. The gameplay consists of the player controlling cities, armies, and special units. Same as other Total War games:-Cities: Generate Revenue, Can Create Units, Expand Your Empire, ect..-Armies: Can Conqour Cities, Defend Against Enemies, Build Forts, ect..-Special Units: Spy For Subertufuge, Assassin For High Targets, Generals, ect..The main goal is the take over a certain amount of Cities before you hit a designated time period. You can fight the battles over an instant computer generated decision or you can manually control your troops on the battlefield.  Diplomacy can be made with other factions for things like trade, alliances, and much more.I enjoyed this game for the most part. While on the other hand I would recommend buying the other Total War games. Namely Rome: Total War the original and Medieval II: Total War.Thanks for reading.

content:
Posted: January 17, 2014
												The Total War series, who hasn't heard of it? As like all excellent Total War games I recommend you take the time to play and enjoy it in all of its glory.Compared to previous games this one has improved graphics, more complex and in depth micro management and introducing for the first time real time naval battles. What makes this game stand out from the other games in the franchise ( & makes it more interesting) is that you have several major & micro theatres of war. Since the games is set in the time of the 17th century gunpowder units & cannons are a standard sight on the battlefield which may confuse older TW players since the main part of the battle isn't a big mellee charge with an onager or two onager to provide some support but here  its all ranged and contains a lot of artillery supprt. The campaign is a little better than in the previous games because the enemy & allied nations are no longer idly passive. The multyplayer has undergone a welcoming change and contains a ranking system & achivements. One of the differences in the games is also that most nations units are the same and the differences between them are their stats, but this is no big problem.On the overall the game is a great step forward from the previous TW games & I recommend this game to every strategy game enthusiast.In the case that I have forgoten to mention anything or the articlle was too subjective please inform me and I will correct it.Thank you.

number of helpful: 9 of 11 people (82%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 6, 2012
												Empire Total War is the continuation of the Total War franchise bringing it into the Napoleonic era of muskets and cannonballs and while Empire manages to maintain many of the good qualities from the series it brings very little new to the table and the ghosts of old flaws that's brought along makes it a very mixed experience.Rome Total War have become the benchmark by which the new Total War games are made. Almost every feature and design direction taken in Medieval 2 and Empire comes directly from Rome with no alterations or improvements made and while Rome was a great and innovative game the qualities that made it so are no longer unique to the Total War series and Empire suffers because of it.If you have somehow never played a Total War game before it can be explained fairly easily. You take command of a nation on a turn-based grand strategy map where you build up your cities and recruit armies. Eventually your enemies will meet up with the armies of other nations and you are thrown from the big strategic map into a real-time 3D tactical battle map where you have direct control of the units of your army as you try to defeat the enemy army.The strategic map has perhaps always been recognized as the greatest weak point in the Total War games and Empire continues this tradition. The turn-based model was never made with the same care as the turn-based games of old and this shows when a small army can walk past an army ten times it's size, conquering cities and raiding the countryside with impunity and still get far enough away that the larger army won't be able to catch up with it creating a sort of cat and mouse gameplay that does your enjoyment of the game no favors.Some improvements have been made over the previous games, most notably the introduction of a tech tree that, while still based on buildings in your various provinces, gives you a more open approach to customizing your nation. The diplomacy is as broken as ever and the AI still seems completely incapable of even the simplest tasks. The AI on the campaign map is so bad that if it wasn't for the ludicrous amount of cheating it does on the higher difficulties you would be winning every campaign in ten turns or less.The meat of the game and where Total War made it's name however is the battle map. Gone are the flaws of the campaign map and all that is left is glorious battle with thousands of soldiers at your command.The problem here however is one that has plagued the Total War series since it's beginning but is even more apparent now that it's made the jump into Napoleonic line combat. The AI is useless. It's not just that the AI is bad, it's that it cannot perform even the simplest of tasks which makes battles against it so trivial that it's almost painful at times. You would think that the developers would have discovered a way for the AI to maintain a formation beyond the first shot fired but every time it happens, the AI falls completely apart.The simplicity and limits of the game engine is also beginning to show as even though your soldiers are armed with musket and bayonet instead of sword and arrow now the battles still play out in much the same way as in previous games. This might be fine for a Rome or a Medieval 2 but Empire tries to emulate a very different age of war and it does not quite meet the standard of that era. Particularly if you've played the Take Command series of games you will begin to notice just how simple the tactical elements of the game have become.The battles are beautiful and your soldiers look impressive as they march forward in formation and the sounds are top quality.If someone who had never played a Total War game before asked me for a recommendation I'd tell him to get the newest one. Empire Total War might be a better game than Rome Total War but that is only a question of age. The Total War series used to be innovative, now they're just shallow repeats with little to look forward to.

number of helpful: 11 of 15 people (73%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2015
												Empire: Total War is a rather fun combination of real-time tactics and turn-based strategy. Overall the Fifth game of the Total War series, this was the first Total War game I have played, and I enjoyed it a great deal. I started off with the tutorial, which covers both ground unit real-time tactics, and naval warfare. Following this fast-paced, easy to use tutorial, I began playing from the Settlement of Jamestown. The learning curve was very easy with this game, and it was surprisingly fun for a turn-based game. Normally, I don't find these types of games enjoyable, but there was something about Empire: Total War that had me wanting to keep playing. Historical challenges are available, including several notable historic battles, The Battle of Brandywine Creek, Fontenoy, and so on. Conquest is the ultimate objective of the game and this can be done using not only military units, but Exploration, Trade, Politics, and founding other colonies. You have the option of playing almost a dozen different main factions. Campaigns allow you to play through American colonisation such as Establishing the colony of Jamestown, to the French and Indian conflict, and even the War for American Independence. I really enjoyed the historical aspect of this game, and also how it is part turn-based and part real-time strategy. I think Empire: Total War does a good job of weaving the two separate game styles together into a seamless whole. I think based off my enjoyment of this game, I may enjoy some of the other Total War titles as well.

Every segment of this game is awesome. There every details, forts castles naval battles (i dont enjoy it because it is not funny but everybody except me found it funny), diplomatic relations etc. But if you finish it single multiplayer will be waiting for you, and believe me it wont be easy as against computer. You can play naval and land battles or have long-period campaign with you or without your friends

content:
Posted: March 27
												A bold spin on the series which mostly pays off. Co-ordinating colonial era armies across Europe, The Americas, The Middle-East, and India is an impressive and breathtaking scope for the game! Commanding armies is a far more engaging and complex experience, with ranged units now the norm, adjusting established tactics from the previous games. Yet they are not distant, and combat is even more intense, with melee exchanges, cannon bombardments, and siege fixtures all in a day's battle!  Naval combat works well, and is a great change of pace! A significantly more intricate world map makes developing your provinces a much more mindful process, and the complexities of the enlightenment world mean you'll enjoy the tedium of empire running!  It is somewhat imbalanced, with the starting positions of each nation varying, meaning you'll have to play a certain way with each nation. It does greatly increase your interest in not only history, but politics, philosophy, religion, economics, and anthropology making it suprisingly educational! Well worth your time and money!

content:
Posted: May 14, 2014
												Still alive and kicking as one of my favorite strategy game of all time. Albeit released in 2009, the game is not as smooth and polished as Napoleon Total War. There are small glitches here and there, but you sort of learn to work around them. Nothing game-breaking.Unfortunately, Creative Assemblies has yet to optimize the multiplayer experience. So a lot of games may drop, lag, have cheaters who don't follow rules, and just downright noobs who don't know what the'yre doing and there's not much player-side control over it. However, with its flaws, I still find the multiplayer to be much more balanced and enjoyable than Napoleon Total War. Granted I play native americans most of the time, I find that the factions have many different strengths & weaknesses, and the diversity of playing style and tactics are endless. It's also really fun to♥♥♥♥♥♥arrogant people off by beating them with mere Axes and Arrows. I also find the strategy to be much more in-depth than Napoleon. NTW just relies on stretching out lines, artillery barrages, and cavalry charges. In empire you have to be much more selective with how you form and move your infantry on the battlefield and which units to assign to different tasks. Are the expansions worth it? If you want to play online, definitely as it will keep you in equal balance with other players, although you can still win without them. For single player, not really, as downloading expansions like darthmod will give you tons of interesting added-on units.I don't have over 1500 hours in this game for nothing. Jump in and play. The learning curve is tough at first, but playing online is a good way to get good fast and blow through enemies both in singleplayer and multiplayer.

												After 8 years of playing this and later Total War titles, this game, by my reflection, is like it's one of those classics in the franchise where you aren't really too blogged down into complicated politic machinations and leadership of your armies can be really interchangable as simply to click a button to recruit a General/Admiral without any having to go through your family tree or random event of Shogun to recruit a general to actually lead your men to battle. This game deserves a award to be one of the classical games ever created.Few of the great things that is missing from the later games have to be the fact you aren't allowed to simply research multiple topics at once when you have a few educational schools operational, 2 tax meter bars for both the middle class/nobility (who are responible for finance growth) and lower class pesanets (population growth) in different continents, able to build and upgrade roads at will (regarding Warhammer and Rome 2), and the ability to change your country's government type after angering 1 of 2 public classes.If this game ever get a number 2 game, I really hope they'll let us manipulate the family tree (Protestant, Catholic, many sons as Ottoman empire, or Maratha), a few different histortic figures that could be recruited as generals/admirals, could go a little more deeper within Africa and could play one of the few African factions as well as Asia, create a few more regions and factions for Europe threater, and the capability to erect a few more Region Capitals into the America as time go by.All in all, this game is pretty good if you happen to like the gunpowder era and different terrain types that change up your battle strartegy as well as to fight sea battles with your sail ship and more importantly.... simple faction management.

content:
Posted: January 19, 2014
												One of the most flawed Total Wars but also one of the largest most ambitious ones. A new engine, full of bugs, a crippled new AI system and a poorly explained game. Time has fixed those issues and it's now the best running large scale Total War. To enjoy it you only really need to accept guns in your Total War. You can always fix your bayonets but never leave your guns at home.Fight and conquer across three theaters of war, the America's, Europe and Indian sub continent. Play with all the larger colonial powers, the (former) colonies and the warring Indian factions. Re-establish the Ottoman Empire or do make some oversea colonies for Prussia that it never had.It's a bit aged, lacks the fancy features you will find in Rome 2 and the AI still has some glitches but a lot can be modded out and overal it's way better then Rome 2, larger scale then Napoleon and more diverse then Shogun 2.

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 16, 2016
												As someone who has been traditionally partial to medieval armour, weapons, and aesthetic, I originally didn't think style of warfare in the early modern period or the "Black Powder" style of warfare prominent in the 17th and 18th centuries was particularly fascinating and appealing. This was largely due to the inaccurate portrayal of the grim realities of warfare in contemporary period works at the time. however, as a history major who became acquainted with enthusiasts, connoiseurs, and aficionados of this style of warfare. it was their presence which inspired me to take the time to learn about the politics, warfare, society, and culture of the 17th and 18th centuries. it was through my studies that I came to understand how intense the aesthetic and experience of warfare was during the early modern period of european history. most artistic interpretations by the period of warfare's contemporaries as well as much of our modern interpretations of this style of warfare in both games and films make little effort in the way of expressing the visual, physical, and emotional brutality and intenseness that many young men and seasoned veterans had to face in the early modern period. advancements in military technology such as those made in firearms and artillery transformed the face of warfare forever as opposed to the melee and armourcentric style of warfare that happened in the middle ages and the renaissance. Thus, with these new technological advancements came new, and might i argue, scarier and more visceral kinds of human cruelties and brutalities that made fighting and killing far in excess of the limits of the raw powers of the human body. The human element of warfare was also highly elevated in response to these new evolutions in the nature of warfare. with the advent of military drill and training, the physical and mental fitness and discipline of the soldiers of this period were arguably superior to the serjents, men at arms, archers, and crossbowmen who peopled the infantry of the medieval era. with the exception of the aristocratic knights who were trained from birth to be expert killers and equipped with the finest weapons, armour, and mounts. medieval infantry to the best of scholarly observation and research were fairely weaker and undiscplined in contrast to the line infantry and footmen of the early modern period, who were typically organized into a line of battle and were expected to depend on discipline and sheer individual courage to hold the line of battle in the face of opposing firepower. However, the novelty that I came to appreciate most about the warfare and military aesthetic of this time period was the surprising amount of melee and close combat that was used in this battle, with the development of the lighter, more efficient flintlock muskets and the extinction of renaissance "Pike and Shot" formations in favour of the plug bayonets and their later innovations. regiments of line infantry would often resort to close combat or melee, which would remain strategically and tactically sound both as a means to save ammunition and fight on terrain where "The lne of fire" would be a strategically unfeasable means to fight an opponent, such as the narrow corridors of an urban settlement, strategic bottlenecks like the crossing of a bridge or the breach of a fortress, or even certain narrow and uneven terrain where froming a line of attack would be impossible due to the strategic limitations of the terrain. The other occasion where close combat and melee would also remain in a position of strategic and tactical importance in this age of warfare would be through the use of cavalry. while black powder warfare would influence the strategic and tactical use of cavalry with smaller firearms such as carbines and pistols, close combat cavalry charges with "cold steel" such as sabres and lances would continue to be the weapons and tactics of choice for many, if not most generals in the 17th and 18th centuries. This understanding of the strategic and tactical importance of close combat and melee in early modern warfare would be enough to spark my enthusiasm for both the warfare and history of this time period. however, in coming to understand the aesthetic innacuracies of modern portrayals of medieval soldiers and warriors. i have come to realize that the rise of standard issue military uniforms is a novelty of early modern european warfare in this time period. and thus, military attire of this period was both aesthetically superior to all its predecessors from the medieval and classical periods, and would remain the alltime epitome and gold standard of military attire that would serve as the foundation and inspiration of later forms of military uniform.Lastly, Through my personal understanding of the military expoits of the French Emperor and General Napoleon Bonaparte and his experiences leading french armies during the revolutionary and napoleonic wars. I have come to believe, taking into consideration napoleon's love for classical greek and roman military history as well as his mathematical expertise in understanding the nature of probability and calculated, strategic planning. That the individual tactics and overall military strategy of the black powder warfare of the 17th and 18th centuries centuries are largely inspired by scholarly research and understanding of military warfare as practiced by the ancient greeks and romans. The rennaissance, or the beginning of the early modern period in the 15th century was marked by an intense fascination and study of classical texts from ancient greece and rome. while originally preserved and interpreted by the literati of the roman catholic church, a growing secular interest and interpreation of these ancient texts was beginning to take prominence amongst the scholarly community of the renaissance onwards which would affect and improve all manner of life and society, and warfare and combat were no exceptions from this advancements made in the study of these antiquated texts. the organization, structure, tactics, and strategic docrines of the black powder warfare the 17th and 18th century were arguably inspired by scholarly research and interpration of greek and roman military treatises and manuscripts as well as the personal military exploits by classical greek and roman generals like Julius Caesar, Alexander the Great, and Leonidas. Both the Impact and influence such texts would have on the developments of early modern warfare would be epitomized in Napoleon's battles such as rigoli, austerlitz, and liepzig, and toulon where application of the principles behind Spartan, Macedonian, and Roman military tactics would would result in triumph for napoleon and the french empire that would result in france being the first european country to dominate europe since ancient rome. Due to the multitude and the genius of napoleon's many military victories, his battles and military exploits would continue to be studied in the presitigious setting of military academies to this very day, and the accounts of napoleons military triumphs and those of generals like him, as well as the treastises and manuscripts by military theorists of the time such as carl von clausewitz would serve as the foundational material for which all aspiring military officers to this very day continue to study as a means of developing a knowledge base for military thinking.In conclusion to all my points. My studies of the politics, warfare, and military theory of the early modern period have opened me to chossing this game as my alltime favourite total war game. even moreso than medieval II total war, my traditional favourite of which I have spent 2000 or so hours on. For all of you who enjoy swords, armour, and melee, and hack and slash style rpg and action games, I wouldn't recommend this game to you unless you have the openness and curiousity to learn about and appreciate the political and military history of this time period.

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 27, 2016
												Note: I only run one mod! It sort of alters my review.. for the better IMHO! Well anyway, its more-or-less a community patch that fixes many complained about aspects of the vannila version and tweaks certain gameplay mechanics for the better. It also alters some minor campain cosmetics, and adds a TON of very usefull, realistic different units which add to each faction's uniqueness even more! The mod is called DarthMod Empire 8.1 and I totally recomend it as well!Now... the review:Before Steam, I played the vanilla version for well over 300 hours, 99% singleplayer. For whatever reasons Total War MP doesn't do it for me like say.. Age of Empires 2 MP does.This is my favourite game out of the Total War series, often taking the spot as my favourite strategy game in general. I love the scale of it all. One can really get satisfied by upgrading and fighting for your distant colonies! This game is HUGE! Playing the "Grand Campain" on "World Domination" mode may take 10+ hours to fully complete. The sea battles are hard, but very fun! Managing an armada is quite a task, hopefully you've done the proper research! The race against other faction's scientific clocks is on, as Empire lets one build schools and send schollarly gentlemen to research new technology!If you're a fan of previous Total Wars, you might be overwhelmed with all the new features and mechanics, but TRUST ME it will grow on you!If this is your first Total War game, you're in for one heck of an experience as well!Once you see the whole mini-map one solid color, and that color is your factions color, you will share the same satisfaction I have gotten many a time from Empire!

content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												This game has a special place in my heart, because it is the game that really got me into the Total War series.  The main thing I like about this game, is the campain map.  technically, this map doesn't have the most settlements in the entire series, but it has the biggest map in any of the games.  You can conquer India, North America and the tip of South America, Carribeans, and Europe.  This gives it a more important feel and that your actions effect more people.  I also love the variation of units for each faction.  The american army had better skrimishers than the English, but the English's line infantry were more regimented and didn't break as easly.  I also love the audio for this game.  I would find myself scrolling up to a single unit and just listening to how well in sounded when he shot his musket.  This is also the first in the series to introduce naval battles that you can play which look beutiful, but can be confusing.  The bad part is that the A.I in this game is some of the worst I have ever seen.  Half the time, they don't even move, and the other half, they just charge at you with no strategy whatsoever.  To sum it up, this game is set in my favorite time period, and besides the cluncy AI, this game does the time period justice.

number of helpful: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 7, 2015
												It's hard to make a decisive yes or no recommendation for Empire: Total War.On one hand, it's one of the glitchiest games in a series infamous for it's bugs. At it's worst, units refuse to move, stop to reform into positions you didn't tell them to, or sometimes even refuse to fire altogether. Thankfully, glitches of this magnitude are rare, but can sometimes be bad enough to cause you to lose battles because your units simply don't follow orders.On the other hand, it's the largest Total War game. You can create colonies in, and be actively engaging in wars, across three different continents- Europe, Asia (both Asia Minor and India), and America. There's less faction variety between groups of the same continent (for example, European armies are very similar), but the variety comes in when an army of one continent engages the forces of another. Europeans, Ottomans, Indians, and Native Americans all fight differently.As well, Empire takes place in a hugely underrepresented time period. Very few games take place in the 1700's, and Empire does a great job of representing musket warfare. Combat is slower-paced than games like Rome or Shogun 2, and tactics are focused on gaining artillery advantage.I end by recommending the game, since I enjoyed it, but your enjoyment depends strongly on your interest in the time period, and your tolerance to bugs.

content:
Posted: December 14, 2015
												In 1706, I, leader of Russia, conquered Crimea with General Ivan Mazepa leading my troops into battle.In 1707, the Crimean people rose up and overthrew the garrison I placed in their lands.In 1708, with Prince Anikita Repnin leading a second army while General Mazepa was tied up in Dagestan, I marched against them and besieged their holdings in Bakchisaray. Rather than give up without a fight, their forces left the city and attacked my army. I placed my troops on a sloping hill nearby, entrenching my infantry and cannons while my cavalry lay in wait at the crest, ready to charge. I had over 1900 battle-hardened troops at my disposal, veterans, all. They had over 2000, but were mostly comprised of peasant militia, with only a single troop of cavalry with their leader. With the elevated and fortified position at my disposal, I waited for their army to cross the valley below. Their leader rode out ahead of their infantry to scope out the battlefield. As soon as he saw what was waiting for him and his men, he turned and ran all the way back to the city, without so much as a word to his infantry, who kept marching up the hill in the face of artillery barrage from my cannons. By the time the Crimean army reached the top of the hill, two of their regiments were already routed, peppered by my infantry's guns after they were too close for effective bombardment. After 5 regiments of my cavalry charged along their flank, their forces were shattered completely and routed.By the end, over 75% of their forces were dead on the field, with less than 25% of my own joining them, most of whom were merely injured and would live to fight another day.Empire: Total War called this a "Heroic Victory". It did not feel heroic. Perhaps granting them a period of tax exemption will take the edge off…

content:
Posted: March 21, 2016
												Empire: Total War.This game is, beyond a doubt, one of the most uninspiring games of the Total War series that I have had the pleasure of playing.  It has so many bugs, you'd think of calling your local pest control.  The portraits for the characters in the game are..lackluster.  They didn't even bother to give the people in the portraits a background, at least in my experience with the game.  The Battle AI is absolutely random, having some brilliant moments of high-stakes deployment, but other times losing a battle they should clearly win.  I myself survived a nasty battle, playing as Sweden.  I had four regiments of line infantry, and was attacked by nearly a stack of Austrian militia and line infantry, yet I still won because the Austrian soldiers actually refused to press forward and engage me.That last bit is the heart of the issue; this game, as incredible as the potential was for a world-wide, 18th century-based game, it is seriously undercut by the odd decisions that were undertaken. For example, I don't know who's idea it was to make every single siege battle on a city with walls look identical, but that was lazy work.  Even as far back as Rome: Total War, cities had varying shapes and sizes to their walls.  Yet things are identical, here, in the 18th century?  A time marked by decidedly huge differences in everything from one cities' religious tolerance, to troops per unit, to the ideals of the local monarch?  Creative Assembly, please.  We would rather you take longer and give us a better experience, than to hurry up and weaken the magic of your earlier works.But, you may be reading this, and seeing that I still recommend this game.  Why is that?Because this game does many things very well indeed.  When at 'ultra' settings, this game is very, very beautiful.  Crisp uniforms, detailed smoke clouds from mass musket volley fire, the reflective water on the campaign map.  I find it all very much a step into a new era of Total War.  And the audio is impressive, as well.  The sound of hundreds of men running and shouting in combat, the sound of cannon barrages firing and then the thumping clash of the shells landing upon the enemy, the officers' barking orders, to which a drum plays the command to the men.  As a fan of history, I can't help but find myself fully immersed in the sounds of the battle, despite the lackluster AI ability.There is, however, a much larger reason to play this game.  A reason that fits nearly every single game since 2000.  What am I talking about? Modifications.The community for this game have made hundreds, if not THOUSANDS, of modifications for this game, ranging from changing the accuracy of the men in each regiment, to a complete and total overhaul of the game...including ridding the game of most of the issues that it was saddled with upon its release.So yes, this game is far from perfect.  It does have many issues.  But, in the end, I will gladly recommend this game to any fan of historical affectations, or even simply those of a curious mindset.  Because despite this game not being perfect, it brings enough to the table to keep those that are willing to work through the issues entertained.

content:
Posted: January 9
												Spoiler Free Review:I always write that first bit, not wanting to ruin the game for someone, but this time it's funny cause seriously, it's history...Anyway, Empire: Total War is pretty old at this point, Rome: Total War II being out, but I'm finally hitting this one up for achievments and having played a few quick games, I quickly was drawn back into the gameplay and time period.  Like all Total War games, you'll spend most of your time on the battle map and the campaign map.  The battles themselves are quite engaging.  Other reviews have complained about the AI, I suggest they bump up the difficulty level.  The AI is dynamic, and when playing multiplayer vs the AI you can set up several different scenarios to test the Napolean in you. The campaign map often gets cluttered and is hard to manage in late game once you actually have money to spend.  The main con for me on this one was the frustrating arrangement of assasins, clerics and gentleman, the when they have it organized and being able to access them every turn was just a frustrating experience compared to more modern Total War games.Recommendation:Release date: 9 out of 10Now - 1/2017: 6 out of 10 - but, still worth playing if you like Total War games.Played on: i7-6700, 16gb Ram, GTX 1070

Posted: January 1, 2014
												Excellent game with unlimited re-playability. Graphics are very good. Technological advances make a huge difference. Real time battles are easy to control and strategy oriented as opposed to a huge brawl. Naval battles are good as well as important cosidering the florins to be made by controlling the trade routes. Three continents to conquer as well as the trade areas offers a huge world. Downside is AI is still not too bright but it can still beat you if you push into enemy territory too deep ,too fast.AI is not totally incompetent though, build up an area and leave it unprotected and someone may decide to invade no matter how far behind the lines, enjoying your previous money making territory as their own.Yes, seaborne invasions of England do occur .Over 1200 hours and still enjoy this game .Maybe i just enjoy the warfare of this era .Never trust the Maratha Confederacy.

content:
Posted: April 14, 2014
												If you like stategy game amd/or the 18th centry warfare? This game is perfect. Apart from some graphical issues and on easy or normal (which all the people who say the game's AI is horrible seem to play on) the AI is just about as good as a 3 year old child.  Apart from that, the game offers over 10 diffrent nations to play as (each with their own starting areas, and unique troops)  real time battles, naval battles, send trade ships to go get you  trading goods to make a big profit from, and if i was to name all the reasons this game was great, the list would never end.Some of my favorite features are liberate nations(learn how to do by guides or the internet) and get protectorates, and wars of sucsession (which are normal wars but when you leader dies this is most likely to happen).  Troops range from militia to the elite british cold stream guards or provencial cavalry (militia cavalry pretty much) to the polish winged hussars and even demi cannons (stationary, low firepower artillery) to mortars, howizters, normal cannons, to low firepower but mobile horse artillery. Or maybe want to be ahead of the other nations techonoligy wise? Build schools and colleges and send gentlemen theri to reaserch military tech, infantry like bayonets,0rtillery for better cannons and better amunition, or naval for better ships, speed and less chances of misfires. Industrail for your better building that get you alot of money, like ironworks, or to make you get even more money from them. And finaly is, enlightment technolegy. This is for getting better schools to reaserch faster, do research faster, better tax income, better trade and even some trade ports.Hope this helped if you want to know the very basics of this game (it is some what complex but it is still easy to learn

content:
Posted: March 22, 2012
												This game is epic and is way better than all other stategy games that I have ever played. The possibilities in what to do with your ever expanding empire are many; you can either try stay true to how history really was or utterly change it, depending on your desire. Of course the AI doesn’t follow the book so you’ll always see the Indian nations trying to form a colony in America or even claim Europe as their own. Every action you do will affect how other nations think of you, so you can't just use trickery on other nations and expect everyone else to think nothing of it. You must have the face of a gentleman and the mind of a warrior to succeed.The cons of this game is that there should be more to the diplomatic side, not a simple case of "give me 20,000 coins and I will make peace." I'd like there to more structure and an ability to properly formulate treaties that result in the loser giving annual payments to the victor after a war etc. There should also be the option to lend out units to allies and they should be much more effective, instead of just having armies doing nothing they actually invade and provide support to the player. Finally, I feel that it conquering a region shouldn't be a case of simply taking the regional capital, the fact that armies can raid factories and farms etc, as well as occupy them, it should give the option for that nation to incorportate this into their own empire, therefore reducing the size of the region that lost these buildings and also providing more tactical gain. It would make conquering regions much more realistic in my opinion. I've not played all of the Total War games but from what I have played, I feel that these cons stretch across the whole series and not just Empire: Total War.9/10

content:
Posted: July 24, 2016
												I've really enjoyed playing Empire: Total War.It has the perfect balance between detail and size. Medieval II: Total War, for instance, has so much detail it's hard to look at.But Empire is in that happy zone of size versus detail. It has great replay value, because of the level of gameplay details. At the same time, it doesn't get bogged down by virtue of being too detailed. This keeps the gameplay moving. I find it particularly refreshing in a Total War title, since I love playing them but get tired of the later-game level of nation management. In short, it doesn't drag you down with administrative tasks as the game gets into the later stages. You can keep conquering enemy nations, instead of keeping your nation afloat with never-ending building management, like in the original Medieval: Total War.The level of advice in the game is perfect for newbies, or for players returning after a long hiatus. It really holds your hand and shows you the ropes, all without being too intrusive. After you've wrung all you can from the advice, you can turn it down or off.The new battle mechanics of using largely gunpowder troops is a switch for Total War. Of course, previous titles were dominated by hand-to-hand combat with pikes, swords, and the like. Lining up blocks of infanty, by contrast, may get boring after a while since it has less detail. But that depends on the type of player you are.Instead of concentrating all of a province's buildings in the region capital, there are now buildings spread throughout the province. For instance, farms, universities, and industrial buildings are spread throughout the province. This makes the game more interesting to look at, since it isn't a meaningless landscape dotted with region capitals. It also gives an added stragegic element to the game: you can pillage these buildings, and thus remove the benefits they provide the other nation. For instance, you can pillage a university and thus take it out of action. It then can't do research for the nation you're fighting. These buildings can be repaired for cash in one turn. But still it puts a monkey wrench in the works, especially if it's an advanced building which is expensive to repair.The different strategic regions (Europe, The New World, India) feel very balanced. It's especially fun to be fighting in North America around the time range of the American Revolution. India feels very boring, since it's basically an inverted triangle. But still, it has a meaningful level of detail to it. It doesn't just feel like a sideshow, though you can ignore it if you wish.I like that you can send trading ships, called Indiamen, to different places in the world to bring back valuable resources. So for instance, you can dispatch an Indiaman to the west coast of Africa to bring back ivory for your nation to sell to other nations. It's a good source of income, and I like the reliability and simplicity of it. It's a very nice touch.Diplomacy has a good deal of detail. For instance, if you're allied to a nation, break your alliance with it and then attack it, you'll get a permanent negative rating with most of the nations of the world. They don't like treaty violators! It makes them think twice about engaging in any deals with you. So be careful who you ally with. Don't do it as a convenience which you intend to break 10 turns later. Additionally, there are "historical grievances" between different nations based on their actual history. So for instance, the United Provinces have historical grievances with Spain because of Spain's attempts to conquer the nation. It adds a nice amount of...landscape to diplomacy. It doesn't feel like you're all just a bunch of random nations dumped into an Earth-like arena with no background. It feels more like actual history.Unfortunately, you can't play as the United States. I guess they thought that it would be impossible to make it into a meaningful power with any realism. Still, it would have been nice to try! So if you would like to have a part in American history, it will have to be secondary part. For instance, in my first campaign I was playing as Prussia and conquered Britain. This sparked the American Revolution by eliminating the Original Thirteen's rulers across the sea. So you can be involved, but only in a secondary way.So if you like Total War games, and especially if you'd like one that moves a little faster than previous titles, give Empire: Total War a whirl!

content:
Posted: December 15, 2015
												Empire TW has the bad wrap that it has a terrible AI. While in a later, sort of patched mode, Empire total war is still an amazing game without any mods at all. People blame Empire for all bad things, but when it comes down to it, Empire TW was the first game with a new battle engine that really had the capability to capture all the glory and death in Europe during the 18th CenturyAD. One of the best parts about it, is the Road to Independence Campaign, or the "America" campaign where you begin as the British in the "New World", and move to rising up and furthering the greatness of the American Republic. Empire TW is truly a great game for those who enjoy American history, and the 18th Century.

content:
Posted: September 18, 2016
												Empire Total War is a great choice if you have an itch for Age of Sail/Gunpowder Era game play. For those of you whom may never have played a Total War title this next part is for you. Total War games are a mixture of 2 common Strategy Game mechanics. You have a campaign board and you have a RTS Battle Mode. For the camapign board think Sid Meyer's Civilization, you control the empires finances, build queues and unit movements in this mode. When you go to fight an enemy force you then go into a RTS mode where the armies involved fight on a map that represents your location on the campaign board. Example, if your forces engage the enemy in a forest then expect the battle mode map to be a forest. If you attack an enemy that is blocking bridge access to the other side on the campaign board you will have to fight accross that bridge in the battle mode map if you want to win. The opposite is true if you are defending. You can choose to automate nearly everything in this game, wether it be taxes, building queues or even land and sea battles. This makes it somewhat easier to learn the ropes of the game as it can be a bit overwhelming at first but I would suggest going straight for the deep end and learn how to do it all yourself.Graphically the game looks great with maxed settings.Audio seems legit most of time but every now and again i notice that some sounds vanish only to return later just as quickly as they left.Quick note on pacing in the game, if you are new or just havent played in a while it can seem slow to start and in some ways it truly is. Trust that patience is a virtue in the early game because when the shiiyat hits the fan it will test you.All in all i think Empire Total War is a great game and can certainly offer you many hours of enjoyment. I recommend this to anyone who likes strategy games and wants a colonial era setting in which to strategize.10/10 would handle the American Revolution properly again10/10 would watch thousands and angry axe wielding natives vanish in a charge on my lines again

content:
Posted: August 30, 2016
												I LOVE THIS GAME. My top two favorite games are Skyrim and Empire: Total War. That moment when your general who has conquered most of Europe and finally dies is heartbreaking, and you may shed a few tears. However, when you meet a nation's most powerful army in the field and this battle will decide that fate of your enemy, nothing is as satisfying as seeing their entire army rout, pursued by your own loyal soldiers. Or when two large fleets partake in a fleet action, and you blow up several enemy ships, capture a few, and sink the rest, you truly feel like a genuine imperialist. Nothing could be more satisfying. Buy this game and give in to your imperialist desires.

content:
Posted: April 10
												To somebody who loves the classic Total War games, this game is crap. To anybody else, this game has a great campaign which combines your skills in grand strategy and real-time battles. If you love the crackling sounds of muskets and the roar of a cavalry charge, you might be interested in this game. No historical uniforms though. Naval combat is kind of bad too. Also, if you're interested in getting either Napoleon: Total War or Empire: Total War, take this information into account. If you like campaigns, get Empire. If you like battles, get Napoleon. Also keep in mind that Empire's graphics are lackluster, while Napoleon has historically accurate uniforms and arguably the second best graphics in the Total War series (Attila: Total War probably is the best for me).Or you can be a money scrub like me and buy both Napoleon and Empire.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 3, 2016
												I am an American, and purchased this while living in Europe. I have spent hours upon hours lost in this game world. It was for me such an amazing experience - my introduction to Steam, the introduction of sea battles in the Total War franchise, the historical period.  It was a step down in some aspects - the "clone" armies vs the unique variations in Medieval II (my favorite Total War to date), the bugs at launch, but the sheer scope and size of it all is absolutely fan-f-ing-tastic. This Total War was the first one that really gave me the feeling of being in control of an alternate history; the leader of a world power. One of the things that I miss a bit was the length of the battles. It's sad to go into a game of the wonderful Attila, such a step up from Rome II (which almost brought me to tears at launch it was so disappointing), and have two massive armies decimate each other in 10 minutes. I played Empire last night, 2v2, and the battle lasted 45 minutes. Half-way through the battle my teammate and I were winning, and then the French overpowered my overly aggressive enemy without me noticing while I defended against the Cherokee, and in the last 10 minutes our enemies completely overcame us. Such a lengthy, brutal battle is typical in Empire, while most confrontations in Rome II and Attila seem like 10-minute-long skirmishes. +1 for Empire: TW. Sieges too were a bit disappointing with focus on forts vs towns, but the towns you do get to fight in usually make for exciting urban combat situations. Overall, not my favorite Total War, but heads-and-shoulders above anything else out there for this time period. Thank you Creative Assembly - you're not perfect, but your games have been my favorite for over a decade.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 27, 2014
												I think i reviewed this game shortly years ago so it's time to re-iterate when it's 100% sure no patches are coming. Stay away. Unless 1) you get this very very cheaply. 2) and you have a zen-state mind where you just accept the the fact that 'you hit caca and caca does not hit you'. You need to loose all hope to begin with. Frustration leads to anger, anger leads to... well you know. Prepare to constantly save and have a huge library of saves as sometimes without any warning 1-3 of your latest saves just becomes corrupted so you need to go back quite some time to be able to resume your game. Sometimes losing 5-10minutes of progress is a lot. And before trying any mid-to-large sized battles you must exit the game and restart it just to ensure you have max memory available as the leaking kills the game soon. (4gb 32-bit win 7 here but according to forums it does not matter much)Automatic quality settings is a must - not because of FPS - no no thats so pleb. for this game AQ is a defensive measure against crashes. Oh yeah, want to know what my secret sauce for getting both this game and Shogun 2 to work better when it's time to 'get real' and fight a big battle? put gfx settings to lowest. You MIGHT actualy be able to complete the game + save it (without corruption). It does not hurt though to have the will to play the same battle 2-5 times if it crashes. Cheers. and here i just laugh at the idea of buying Rome 2. Never going to happen with any games based on this engine. And to all of those people who have never been hit with these problems: good for you, the sun light shines on you but i don't want to know anything about that. I just don't. TW support  forums, the official and the unofficial ones are places where hope of getting things fixed goes to die.   I love this game to bits as can be seen by the hours clocked on it but playing it sure requires nerves of steel. I have never gotten even close to completing a short game. NOT EVEN CLOSE.  I'll put a thumbs up sign here next to this review so i dont get too much apologist comments. i dont want to hear them. No other game has ever caused more troubleshooting for me during the decades of gaming than this particular turd.

												Well... I may say give an 7.4 Rating on 10. __________________________                                                                                                                          -Basic Introduction- ( And Moments )__________________________A game set in ol' 1700's. The Developers made a good pavement to reach for this, but it has bumps.To be honest the game is really slow to load especially when you buy it, but after time it gets better; in fact it loads in like 2-3 minutes after that. I made a battle in *Road to Independance* , Took one hell of a long time to load -.- so I just had to restart my computer, I know when the numbers are big you have to wait but come on! I lost my patience after 15 minutes. Another flaw is that when I was using my Riflemen to put Stakes in front of my Puckle Guns... Oh! -.- This I hate very much and stupid *Glitch* They turned around took a couple of paces and planted them... facing my dragoons! And away from the Indian cavalry, long story-short I got F***ed ... SO that really sucked xD  Good side is that they have good detail ( Troops, Forts, Seperate Nations, Cannons, and Cavalry, how the Country's are geographically accurate *Mapping* and also Accents =D ) . Sea Battles are cool, got incredible detail, Hilarius when you see the enemy ship blow up xD not so much when it's a Heavy First Rate xD . __________________________                                                                     -Campaigns-__________________________Nice Achievments but sometimes in the Main Campaign they are kinda *twisted*. I mean World Domination is conquering 40 citites? ( Hardest Right?) Short-Long Campaign- Capture 15-25 Cities... Now xD don't tell me this...When in World Domination Prussia needs Brandenburg ( Its own Capital so no prob right? =D ) England Short-Long, well capture Malta ( My own Country =D Some place in India, Merika, have to go to War with em' Ottomans; so Total War right?)I don't know :P__________________________                                                                      -Diplomacy-__________________________Small flaws when it comes to Diplomacy and I'm not alone -.- Ok so ex. I tell France that I want one of their technology in exchange for 3 of mine, They say no... REALLY? no???!!!ok so what am I to do?- Nothing. After some time when you are at war, they offer peace after no war acts happen (Battles) or either just don't quit on the war.. heh :P . In Medieval Total War they have that - Balanced, Generous or Demanding - Note to help set things *equal* when you are at Diplomacy. They could've made that would really help a lot =D---Sometimes the smaller Nations offer you to become their Protector, so yaya! __________________________                                                               -In game Battle ( Land )-__________________________Not anything bad or anything but it sucks that you can't see the FULL VIEW, I mean when you zoom-out, you see part of your army. When you zoom in close it lags so you can't see the *Full Action* =D                                                                 +++++++++++++++++Got a nice N-Zoom, makes you look like you are part of that Battle =D +++Pulls a neat Square Formation for  the Infantry +++Nice Diamond and Wedge Formation for Cavalry+++Neat Graphics for its level+++And nice in-game Commands =D+++Uniforms are played nice+++__________________________                                                                     -Sea Battles-__________________________Very neat Graphics especially for its level =D+++Good use of *Wind* can lead to Victory making it more lively.+++Can turn anybattle to a win. ( May be abit *unlively* )+++Funny moments when the ships explodes xD**                                                                   -----The only *Bad* things about this is when you make a boarding action, never did it* exactly but takes a long time and sucks when doing it =D ( Wait!?, Why did I do a smily? ) xD__________________________                                                                  :(  END  :(Hope you Like and enjoyes it, don't get me wrong =P easy to find flaws but easy to get addicted =D______________________________________________________________________________

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 15, 2014
												Empire Total War is a strategy game like I've never laid eyes on before. It has a brilliant mix between the turn based campaign that leads directly into real time battles. For every unit you can change their rank and file accordingly, change formations, even tell them to skirmish or fire and advance. The game can get repetitive if you don't challenge yourself though so I do recommend leaving normal difficulty as soon as you feel comfortable with the mechanics. Other than that the campaigns are varied with different units you can choose from for each category from elite infantry all the way to morter batteries. I highly recommend both this game and it's successor, Napoleon Total War. I will comment though that Napoleon is not NEARLY as varied when it comes to factions, and is a little lacking in the campaign department. It's a decent expansion though.

number of helpful: 8 of 13 people (62%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 16, 2014
												This is a great entry into the total war franchise. - - - - pros - very balanced - good unit variety- deep strategic possibility s - easy to learn hard to master - - - - cons -very rock paper scissors when you go unit to unit -  laggy online - no longer has a bustling player base - units moral seems really fragile  - - - -wishes - steam mod support This game takes place in the colonial era. So guns play a rather large role in this, and because of the era the guns are mostly single shot muzzle loaders. There are also melee infantry, hoursemen (both armed with fire arms and melee weapons) , and artillery of varying caliber. Landscape is very important in this game because of the surplus of ranged units. Hight as in most games will help your ranged units and slow the advance of melee infantry. Artillery is also helped by being put on hills and the like.In all honesty melee is not as important in this game as in others. But melee troops are still very useful. Because most units are ranged a melee unit can very quickly destroy their moral or the unit in general. But this goes the same both ways because of the ranged unit being well ranged. So melee are best for ambushes or holding walls.One of the cons i mentioned above is that moral seems really fragile. Units can brake in a mater of SECONDS. This would be ok if it was mere cannon fodder but even the most elite of units can be broken after one or two volleys of fire then at other times they charge though no problem. The moral system seems unstable and inconstant.  -1 point As mentioned above all the factions are relatively balance because they share alot of units with small changes. The only faction that is at both a disadvantage and an advantage is the Indian nations. Because they are over all more stealthy they are good for ambushes, they also have better melee units from the start of the game, but their range is a lot lower then the European nations.The online is very laggy if more then two players are involved. This is rather common in total war games. So unless playing 1 on 1 online or playing though LAN i would recommend not putting your hopes into online -.5 pointsA small complaint i also have is the lack of online campaign. Many other total war games both before and after have this feature.As mentioned above the unit to unit comparison is very rock paper scissors. But many strategy games are like this and with proper strategy and high ground advantage it can be changed.so because you can counter it I think it evens out.so over all i think it is a 8.5/10

number of helpful: 9 of 15 people (60%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 6, 2015
												I've tried to justify this game in my head so many times, but I've reached my limit; Empire: Total War is complete garbage. There's a fantastic game hidden deep beneath the countless bugs, but these bugs are so game-ruining that even after six years Empire feels like it's unfinished and still in development. The A.I is ridiculously poor, during sieges the infantry refuse to shoot, or cannons knock down their own walls, and if the computer is the attacking faction the game seems to know that the A.I won't be able to attack on its own, so it cheats. I've started sieges with sections of my walls already knocked down, and sometimes the enemy need only come into close proximity of my gates for the computer to unlock them for the A.I. More often than not the infantry units simply walk around the map, allowing themselves to be killed or routed. I've installed one or two mods to help with the A.I, which has improved it slightly, but sieges still remain horrible affairs, with soldiers trying to shoot through walls, or even killing men on their own team. The combat aspect of this game is utterly broken, and considering that this is the crux of Empire's gameplay it leaves me to wonder why it has such glowing reviews.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2015
												Ah, the game that introduced me to Steam and was my first Steam game.  CAs first real crack at focused firearm comat.  This one saw many ups and downs but is still one of the most memorable Total War Games for me, though not the best.  It was a truly experimental title for CA.  A new engine, completely different combat mechanics, the first title to allow manual naval combat, a new era, one of the biggest campaign maps yet, and the introduction of a tech research tree.  It was a breathtaking sight that, once growing pains had passed, delivered a monumental Total War experience that remains the title for which I most want a sequel.  Fall of the Samurai showed just how far CA has come with this style of warfare and I cannot wait.  All that being said, the game isn't without its flaws.  This was the last Total War title lacking cooperative multiplayer, there are a number a bugs, the AI is predictable, especially when they are defending a siege assault, and as with all Total War titles, the AI plays by a completely different set of BS rules.  Including non existant army upkeep, no resistance to occupation, agents with nigh 100% success rates... Even with its flaws, it is a unique Total War title that offers an experience no other in the series can, for now.  Absolutely recommend it.

content:
Posted: December 1, 2014
												In my humble opinion, Empire: TW is the most ambitious installment in the TW series to date.  With almost the whole world as your playground, you are able to build or destroy empires that cover enormous areas.  Only a world on such a scale can truly capture the impressiveness of your achievements, helping you match the greatness of empires and kingdoms now of by-gone years.That said, more up-to-date TW games have better battle mechanics and physics.  The battles themselves, whilst visually stunning, might sometimes leave you scratching your head as to why a perfectly placed unit didnt do what you hoped it would.  Things like line of sight are not as obvious in Empire.  The AI is probably as good as any other, although that isn't saying much.  Programming competitive AI in TW games must be a nightmare and is therefore going to always be a weak spot open for mass criticism.Overall, despite the short comings described, the feel of Empire is arguably unique in the series.  It is one of the few games these days which isnt 'finished' within 10-20 hours.  You can still be playing this game after hundreds if not thousands of hours and seeing new experiences and creating new narratives (if that's your thing).

content:
Posted: June 24, 2016
												This game is easy to learn for everybody who is new to strategy games. The tutorials are really helpfull and in the normal campaigns you'll get hints on how to play with your nation.It is quite historically correct, which makes it also really interesting. And because you can choose your own difficulty it's challenging for beginners as well as more experienced players.You can choose from a bunch of nations to play the campaign with. Thanks to that you can spend many hours on this game without getting bored. The diplomacy features in this game are quite good, but they could be better. Religion is a great factor and the historical alliances are not easily broken, while in reality the nations switched alliances almost every generation.But besides that I'll recommend this game to everyone who likes strategy games or history games and who doesn't like to see to many complicated features to control a nation.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												You see, I bought the elite pack which contains the DLC and original game, although it was a bit pricey...Anyways, back to the game. Empire is quite different from the other games in the series because it allows Naval Battles! On this unique experience, you control your army on the 7 seas, versing A.I. or real people online or locally. It can get quite intense, as your ships may flee if damaged, but there are also contreversol wins!The game also allows you to (as I mentioned earlier) to play online with friends, or random people. The problem with online matches though, is that if your internet is bad, you must drop from the game. This can lead to frustraion from the opposing player. You can also do quick Naval or Land matches (Although, finding a game in the quick section is difficult.) You can team up and join an alliance in online matches too! They are quite intense! I prefer playing with friends, 'cause im so good at the game and I beat them :3.The Total War Series has never been known for graphics, but I have to say this game suprises me. My favourite part is seeing my men run into my enemy and watch the battle. You can see them have little battles with eachother! It looks quite realistic, as after the batttle you can see all the dead men that have fought.Overall this game is meant for RTS players who enjoy a good online battle. This game is simple to manuver and comprehend. This is my favourite out of the Total War series (personally.) Overall, It definately fed my hunger for a good bloodbath and RTS game. I give it a 8.5/10!
