number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 31, 2014
												I completely recommend this game. It's already a few years old, so I would advise to wait for a sale perhaps... but considering that I have spent that many hours on Steam playing this game (and many hours off-Steam as well), even paying the full price does not mean you'll feel ripped off. You're not only buying quite a lot of game with your purchase, you're also buying the best single-player experience any Total War can bring you.Total War is a series that combines the most massive and spectacular battles you will find in any game with the building and managing of an empire in single player. In multiplayer it's the best game of chess you can have. This particular Total War is set in the early Modern Age (1700-1800), and for the first time includes line-infantry with muskets as the backbone of an army and not a melee unit, which makes for a unique Total War. In this era, the European countries were involved in a lot of wars with eachother while they conquered several continents and established trade routs with most of the rest of the world, and I do not know of any other media that encompasses that much of this era like in Empire: Total War.From my point of view, this is the last of the true and classic Total War games. I have played every Total War (including Shogun) and my favorites are Rome 1 (not rome 2, absolutely not rome 2) because of the way it represents the classical era, Empire because I am personally very interested in this era as well and it is unique in the ranged combat with muskets and I love Shogun 2, because it simply has the best multiplayer. There is also a stand-alone expansion of Empire about the conquests of Napoleon, something I had been anticipating for many years, but I didn't like it enough. It's too limited. I also don't appreciate a lot from the medieval era in general. It's chaotic, it's too religious/christian, there is no progress, there is death, decay, famine and the plague and Medieval Total War games represent this fine, I don't like it.Why do I consider this the last Classic Total War? Well, Total War is a game that, as you play, can teach you stuff. Like in Rome1 you learn that clear glass was invented, in Empire you get info along the way about what happened in the 18th century and it was a lot. In fact, the only good description I can find about my 'religion', Secular Humanism, I found in Empire Total War. This is also the last Total War in which the campaign map is open, you can send your armies where you want and you're not stuck in corridors like in the latest installments. However, it is the first Total War to include a tech-tree and naval battles (and naval battles were very spectacular in this era!).The 3 continents you can explore with armies and conquer are Europe, North and Middle America and the Indian sub-continent (you can walk from Western-Europe to India if you please, or sail around Africa). There are also a few trade regions to conquer using just the navy: the east coast of South-America, the west coast of Africa, the strait of Madagaskar and the East-Indies. Every region has it's own feel and it's own enviroments, cultures, empires and people.The units you command are also unique for each culture. Yes, warfare was a lot about standing in lines facing eachother firing lead balls back and forth and then reloading for quite some time, the native americans for instance are better equiped for guerilla style battles combining melee with light infantry equipes with muskets or bow and arrow. Along the tech-tree you unlock new units to build and command, artillery changes from simple big cannons to a whole specrum of weaponry. Ranging from mortars to puckle-guns (rapid fire musket, very early machinegun) and stuff in between. Cavalry also comes in many flavors, dragoons that melee on horseback but function as line infantry dismounted, full melee cavalry and the cavalry even gains horsedrawn cannons as technology is invented. And the ships! Oh man, imagine the big ships of the line with over 40 cannons on each broadside, 2 lines come within eachothers range... just crank up the sound to really loud!Like most Total War games, the game has improved a lot because of mods, Empire is no exception. Even for new players I would recommend to install and use at least Darth Mod, which can be found in the Steam Workshop. More units are also available with mods, but I'm not sure which one to recommend. But the Darth Mod really improves the ai and the feel of the game.Every Total War has it's own features and it's own feel to it. Personally I find this installment the best in single-player of the entire series. I have had some really tight battles in the campaign. In Empire it is possible to position your men in some buildings, so making a last stand gets it's own feeling to it. Your men firing from the windows at incoming soldiers while your lines of infantry try to hold the lines in front of that building, untill the fight turns melee when the bayonets are pointed at eachother.And I haven't even mentioned the historical battles that come with each Total War, you can reenact battles that actually took place and with a historically similar setting and armies to command. Pitching you as Washington vs the Brittish and many others. There is a demo available here on Steam, in it you can play at least one of these historical battles and get a glimpse of what is in store for you when it comes to battles, but if you like games like Civilization or RTS games like Age of Empires and you haven't tried Total War at all, you will love it!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 30, 2015
												Empire: Total War takes us away from the battlefields of both Ancient and Middle Aged Europe and Middle-East and takes us to the Empires of Europe during the 18th Century. Muskets and Cannon now determines who is the most powerful in all of Europe, Improved graphics and gameplay makes the game more exciting and stunning for Total War fans. Campaigns follow George Washington as he revisits the past from the development of Jamestown (1607), to the French and Indian War (1740's to 1750's), and to the American War of Independence (1775-1783). Not only can the battles between the European powers take place in Europe and the Middle-east, but also the Colonies of North America and South America and to the Colonies of India. Trade and expansion is key to your nation's victory, expanding out to colonies and your Empire's borders are crucial. The century turns to the the advancement of technology and development of new forms of Government. A time when the system of Monarchy seems to crumble while Republics and Democracies rise. Revolution and Colonization has made the 18th Century one of the world's most crucial centuries in all of the World's History. Will you reign or will you revoutionize a new Empire, the choice is yours. The times of Royal familes and difference in social class lays in your hands, will you preserve it or will you destroy it?

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 27, 2014
												Soooo, this is my first "Proper" Review, so let's get some kind of system going:First, a overall "look" at the game.Second, the good part's.Third, the bad part's.Fourth, a Summary.Also, note that im bad at spelling, so don't expect it to be good. These review's, in which i plan to do more, are mean't to be quick so don't expect some massive amount of information.----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------So, let's get started:So, what is this game? this is an RTS based in the time era of 1700-1799, focused on the combat system of unit's, usually containing about 120 men, then lining them up to fire, reload, and fire again. and although this sound's dull, it is actually a great system. This is mainly due to the fact that you can do some very intelligent thing's involving cavalary, using real life tactics to win battle's, such as flanking attack's with some light cav to divert their attention. There is also a grand campain option, in which you lead your country through the time period, with the options of building unit's, building's to allow the building of said units and help the economy. There is also a diplomatic system to allow alliances, trading and war. The battle's work by moving armies across the map, then going down into a standard battle. There is also the feature of naval battles, in which you must use the wind and naval positions to your advantage----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------so, let's go through the pro's and con's:Pro's:Great battle's which require a good amount of thinking, and immerse you in the great looking combat.Good match-making and battle options, which allow you to change options such as map, weather, time period and such.Good grand campain, allowing you to make an empire in your vission.Con's:High learning curve, requiring a good few hours to get to grip's with.Linear grand campain, although it allows freedom, it doesn't include the whole world. Also, a lack of countries to choose from  makes it even more linear.Overall, if you like RTS Game's with a good amount of planning and thinking involved, i would rally recommend this game!

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 16, 2012
												Honestly, I have a lot of good and a lot of bad to say about etw......Now this game, it will always hold a special place in my heart. ETW is the game that not only introduced me to the total war series, but it did a damn good job of doing so. Not only that, but it also introduced me to steam itself, being the very first steam game I ever played. There are not many games based in this time period, but ETW gives you the opportunity to dive right into the thick of the 1700s world as a emperor hell bent on world domination, and the route you take to achieve that, is paved by the beating of drums as your musket armed soldiers march along, and the waving of the sails of your mighty navy to the far reaches of the 1700s world. I am making references to the campaign of course, because at first, I cared not about online battles......kinda because I had no internet at the time. Though the community surrounding this game has all but died out, I must testify that it was once very big and very competitive, with many many clans that have come and gone since this game's release, and once I became aware of it, I sought out to claim my own personal glory in many different clan, but only 2 of those clan I remained apart of for years. This game was a great journey and a very worthwhile investment back in the day, but if you just wanna play campaign, then even for that reason I'd reccomend etw. However......now that I have given what was great about this game, now let me address the game's many flaws.......the game itself is buggy to the point where sometimes it will crash for seemingly no reason at all. Units have been known to do some very interesting things that may not put a smile on your face in the heat of a intense battle as well. And even though there are many factions in this game, let me be the one to tell you, the factions are almost the same ♥♥♥♥ing thing, and there are slight differences in play style for each. Basically, you have middle eastern style factions, european style factions << Overpowered and then you have indians who aren't good at all until you get the DLC units for them. Out of those 3 classifications, you have a lot of european factions that have some unique units to each, but for the most part thier the same thing, and use the same basic strategy if your a seasoned veteran of the game like myself. Once you play, and like NTW, ETW feels rather generic and you see it for what it really is. But was ETW truly a fail? Thats a foolish question, for all it's flaws, this game is truly a diamond in the rough and thats the best way to sum it up. If your someone who wants the feeling of conquering the world, I'd highly reccomnd this game to you. If you want a competitive clan community, then I must say, theres not much left these days, but if you want it, by all means, go for it

content:
Posted: February 15, 2015
												I was playing as Sweden first the russian declared war on me, I beat them after about 20 turns or more now my empire is HUGE. So after I beat the russian i took a fleat of ships, loaded them all with line infantry and canons, went to north america attacked the 13 colonies took all there land but also now my british are at war with me so I saild a few ships and army there took them all out, they offer me a peace treaty so I accepted it. Now my empire is really strong I feel unbeatable so I started a campaign on the ottomans lost half of my men against farmers with pitch forks (I had line infantry), finally i took one of the citys of the ottomans. But it was not long untill 3 armys attack my new conquered city, they all have elephants with poeple riding on them with guns so now I lost the battle so my city was recaptured my the ottomans. Now its my turn so I send my men down south to attak the ottomans I attack some of there armys and farms, I could not move my men down any more so i end the turn, all of a sudden the austrian declared war on me, so now I need to attack from 2 fronts. After about 10 turns ottomens and austrian took all of my captured rusian citys, they pushed my back all the way to the motherland, now im ♥♥♥♥ed I half of my army is at north america fighting, so what i did was I loaded all of my men into ships and saild back the sweden it took me a few turns but good thing my men manage to hold the invaders back. So now my whole army is at the motherland, first I tried to make a peace treaty with them but the dident accept so I sent my men to attack but lost to the ottomens now im really ♥♥♥♥ed (at the mean time i lost all my Citys to the natives) so I loaded my last few ships and men and sailed for india I got there after a few turns i attack the united provinces small island in india won the battle also at the same time my main city in sweden was captured by the ottomens good thing i won the battle with the united provinces or it would have kicked my out of the game. So now I have to go eat (Dinner) i was about to save my game then it crashed took me 4 days to play saved only 3 times lost some of my progress but it was still fun to make history and kill hundred of civlian and soilders. 10/10 would play agian

												The Grand Campaign's map (SP) is so large. There's almost whole world geography. But; the diplomacy is not good enough. Crimean Khanate, Degastan and Georgia talk in "Russian Language" but in the history they talk in; Crimean Tatar, Chechen and Georgian languages.And there's Greece talking in Turkish. content:
Posted: November 4, 2014
												Empire: Total War does have some bugs and minor crashes, But if you get DarthMod it makes the game alot better, And also adds in additional units and takes out the crashes and bugs. I really have to say this is a really good strategy game, Imagine your playing against your friend and his army is slowly marching towards yours your heart is beating 1,000 MPH per minute then when they raise their rifles your heart stops then BOOM, The fun just begins. The link for the mod that fixes bugs and adds additional units and fixes crashes and etc is DarthMod the link is http://www.modsaholic.com/forums/index.php/files/file/71-darthmod-empire/ Just click that link and hit download it is a big file 2.80 GB it does upgrade your graphics to make the units more realistic and adds gun sounds and just a all around great Mod. I really love the Total War Series, I recommend this game to everyone. It is history in the makings. It is actually a really fun game even without the mod though, It just fixes the campaign crashes other than that it is just an amazing game, I would say it is worth being in your library. I put so many hours and hard work into this game, It is cheap too. So grab yourselfs a copy and you will really enjoy it.

content:
Posted: December 11, 2016
												I've decided to simply this review into points-No way to make peace without simply fully annexing as AI thinks it's god and will not surrender land -Multiple Bugs-No 3+ Player Seiges-Campaign Map split across 3 continents-Stupid AI cant use ships to transport troops across the ocean and constantly sends offers to sell provinces in eastern russia for scotland (Example) not exchanging colonies or border lands-Combat isn't enjoyable since everybody shoots then everybody charges (Medivel 2 and Rome 1 have much better combat as you have your basic Melee,Ranged,Cavalry)-Napoleon is basically Empire 2.0 But better even if on a smaller scale-Seiges no longer include city-size battles but simply battles over tiny forts-Elite Units (Such as guards) dont really have much diffrence from regular in battles unlike other titles-The other buildings in provinces are just random points for enemies to raid (No forts around the towns though) -City Expansion  is reliant on population whitch never goes up -Capturing a city forces you to wait there to wait there for years to calm it down until you can expand and unlike other titles there are no rebel lands where you can expand so you sit there waiting to be able to attack (Other titles also solve this by giving you to burn and slave options)-Protectorates are useless and all they do is remove the mystique of latin america and replaces it with a big "Spain already owns this and won" sign. Isn't the point of this game to colonise?

content:
Posted: March 15, 2015
												Impossible to make a list of all the bugs in the♥♥♥♥♥♥game. If you dont mind every nation falling into 1 of 3 catagories (European,Indian,Middle Eastern) And all of those nations having the SAME units in a battle, and don't mind constant game breaking bugs, and clones fighting each other, then Empire is ok. Every single European nation has *Line Infantry* Which are EXACTLY the same skin exept differant colors. The Same uniform. So battles look like a bunch of multi colored clones shooting at each other. Theres also *Regament of Horse* Which almost every European nation has by defult and theres absolutly no differance but once again differant colors. Each nation also has the same ships. There are a few units although that differ. If you want some real differance spend your money on DLC for expensive or Overpowered Units. Theres also the unbalanceness of Empire. Say you are playing as Britain and you want to conquer France, France only has 2 regions in Europe, take them, and everything else France has dissapears. Bacically 1 region is almost Entire France, the other one is Alsace Lorraine which has barely any garrison.Theres much more to tell about, if this stuff doesent bother you, go ahead and buy Empire, But 80% of my hours are on Darthmod, which most say took empire from the dephs of a pit and pushed it into something great.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 19, 2014
												This game is completely worth every penny in the price! This is a RTS fans dream come true!Let me hit the highlights of this game:The graphics and sound effects make it feel as if your actually in an 18th century army. When I get off the game, I sometimes feel as if Im getting out of a time machine, bringing myself back from the past, back to the present.Building and researching takes a little figuring out and can be confusing, but you'll see things as you play. Completing the tutorial will also help.On the Grand Campaign, it is CRITICAL you begin recruiting, and researching military stuff immediately. The easier the setting, the lesser the AI will attack you, but they'll come. My favorite faction is Prussia. However, when you first begin the Grand Campaign, there is a ton of factions. Even factions you cant choose from. Usually, around the fourth turn, Prussia and Austria declare war on each other, because they are close to each other and hostile towards the other. So, whichever faction you choose to be, be warned: the factions that are your neighbors are most likely to declare war against you.Once you enter battle, your given time to setup your troops. If your using cannons, it is VITALE you set them up before the battle begins. They setup into firing position slow and can be moved slow. Very realistic, so it takes away any annoying feeling.You will need to build navies. Those can be extra challenging. The cost of a single ship is extra high, so building a huge navy is slow. Its also pretty hard to have multiple huge navies at the same time. Although most helpful, usually its best to build a navy when your ready for use.Naval battles are probably the most difficultest battle. The ships sail slowly. The AI usually starts in a single line, and spreads out, slowly, encircling your ships. These battles vary in time length, usually depending on who has the more battle ships. A variety of ships helps.In the Grand Campaign, they also have notes mentioning historical events, such as Captain Kidd being hung, the start of circus's and much, much, much more.When I tried an online multi player battle, I was in RTS gamers heaven. No matter the AI, playing against an opponent who thinks, is 100 times better. Especially when you win.Overall, if anyone likes history, strategy, thinking, or strategy games, this game is for them! 100/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 7, 2014
												Empire: Total War was the first Strategy game I've played. I saw the game and said "Hmm, looks cool".  I downloaded the demo, and spended about a day, playing each mission.Then i bought the game. It was amazing. Commanding my first empire was a blast, conquering Indian Tribes, and sailing to the Americas, discovering new lands. The AI wasn't the best, so I took a break and downloaded Darth Mod.Then, I jumped back straight onto the game with Darthmod UC. Then I started my 2nd Empire. I realized how better it was, and much more challenging. I kept Darthmod, because it improved graphics, and AI. Then I got used to the game. I decided to begin a bigger Empire with much more enemies. I started focusing on Economy and it really helped. I got trade and towns up. I got so much money, that I made a huge army. I felt so good.Thats when the colonies decided to declare independance. I got pretty mad, so I discovered I could have relations. Know I knew alot of the game. I was ready.I sailed with my allies to the new Americas. There, the war with the Rebels lasted 3 Years in-game. I had a blast battling. I gave some land to my allies in the Americas to avoid rebels. I took the Americas back for myself then. After I had conquered most of the Americas, I decided to move into uncharted land and waters. I found tribes, and made allies, and made new enemies. I was amazed by the game. I conquered many new lands, and made many enemies.My empire became power hungry, and I fell apart. I was so happy, and I enjoyed myself. Just next time, hope to lead a more successful empire.If your looking for a game like this, buy it. The AI is not the best, but there are mods that fix the game. The modding community makes some cool thingsRating 9.8/10AWESOME GAME!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 7, 2014
												Empire: Total War was the first Strategy game I've played. I saw the game and said "Hmm, looks cool".  I downloaded the demo, and spended about a day, playing each mission.Then i bought the game. It was amazing. Commanding my first empire was a blast, conquering Indian Tribes, and sailing to the Americas, discovering new lands. The AI wasn't the best, so I took a break and downloaded Darth Mod.Then, I jumped back straight onto the game with Darthmod UC. Then I started my 2nd Empire. I realized how better it was, and much more challenging. I kept Darthmod, because it improved graphics, and AI. Then I got used to the game. I decided to begin a bigger Empire with much more enemies. I started focusing on Economy and it really helped. I got trade and towns up. I got so much money, that I made a huge army. I felt so good.Thats when the colonies decided to declare independance. I got pretty mad, so I discovered I could have relations. Know I knew alot of the game. I was ready.I sailed with my allies to the new Americas. There, the war with the Rebels lasted 3 Years in-game. I had a blast battling. I gave some land to my allies in the Americas to avoid rebels. I took the Americas back for myself then. After I had conquered most of the Americas, I decided to move into uncharted land and waters. I found tribes, and made allies, and made new enemies. I was amazed by the game. I conquered many new lands, and made many enemies.My empire became power hungry, and I fell apart. I was so happy, and I enjoyed myself. Just next time, hope to lead a more successful empire.If your looking for a game like this, buy it. The AI is not the best, but there are mods that fix the game. The modding community makes some cool thingsRating 9.8/10AWESOME GAME!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 5, 2014
												Its killing me nowBest strategy game everHighly recommend I have been an RTS fan since early on, played all the great names from Command & Conquer to Wh40k: Dawn of War. Of all these games, Empire:TW brought the biggest satisfaction. The game might be getting old now, but it`s glory doesn't fade. Even if you never played Total War games before, this is a must buy for any RTS fan.Starting from the graphics. Like said, some time passed since it`s release, but never the less, when put on max. settings it is still beautiful. The sound is done quite well. I enjoy every round of shots made from the infantery, the roar of canons, the thousands of feet marching to the beat of the drum, the hissing of primitive missiles in the air.....The game itself gives you a lot of feautres. The two singleplayer modes let you play as some of the greatest nations of the time, from Prussia to the Maratha Confederacy (the other SP mode let`s you play as the United States on their way to independence). Your job is to form alliances, make trade, conquer areas, defeat your enemies, develop your nation, and if you feel like it, you can always coup the monarchy and establish a republic. The campaign itself is turn based, moving your armies and agents in a pre-set range of movement each season, governing your cities and doing some diplomacy along the way. The battles on the other hand are real-time, but you can change the speed of battle from slow-motion all the way to fast. The map on which you play on is determined by the region you are fighting in. Battles can be either the classical land battles, sieges or naval battles. If you don't feel like doing a battle, but you have good chances, simply click autoresolve (save the battle just in case you get defeated). The multiplayer is also quite good, letting several players play as their favourite nation and setting up their army. You can join your friends and fight bots, do 1v1, or a large scale battle of up to 6 players 3v3.

Posted: March 12, 2014
												Empire: Total War is one of the two games in creative assembly's Total War franchise that I have had the privledge of playing. After a rough start when attempting to launch the game (and a few crashes in the first few hours of play), I was supprised to find a that this was indeed a great game, and worth the fourteen dollars at which it is currently priced on steam. While the long load times and frequent graphical bugs aren't game breaking, they do definitley do a disservice to what is otherwise a great game. I would recommend this to any total war fans, as well as strategy fans in general.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 21, 2013
												Empire Total War is one of the best games I have ever played. You can play this game in many ways like a Civization game with the campagin map but. It was A LOT of replay value since if you choose to play as a different nation they have comepletley different play styles, units, and diplomecy which makes two play throughs of Grand Campagin completley different. In combat however is where it really shines. The strategy is SO in depth about how to deploy your units, when to deploy your units, and what formation is extremly fun. It is also EXTREMLY detailed as you can zoom in and clearly see your units individually and watch them fight. My favorite part is to look after a big battle at the battlefield where you can look at all of the bodies bc they dont despawn and you can see where they were deployed and how bloody was the combat it is amazing, However the diplomecy can be annoying with the AI and they are kinda dumb but all is forgiven if you choose to go on hard and play the battles yourseld because that is where the focus is.                                                                                  If you are new to the series this is one of the most realistic RTS games out there. I have seen on the Military History Channel a show called Deceisive Battles I believe it was called and they used Rome: Total War to simulate the battles with amazing accuracy. This game came out later than it

content:
Posted: June 27, 2015
												My favourite out of the total war series franchise so far that I have played, but thats just my opinion. It's quite in depth for the era it represents and the game is really enjoyable. I have spent many hours marching my empire towards victory, economically, logistically, militarily and politically. One moment I am a general leading my armies and the next I am a diplomat. Absolutely love this game :) I love the fact you can even personalise your regiments which is added fun.Some down sides are the unit cards could be improved, more locations and more option to customise your nation. Also the diplomacy could be a bit more in depth. Overall a very pleasant gaming experience and will continues to be.But for what it's worth and the price I paid for it I can't knock it and I would reccommend it. Hours of fun and joy thats what I look for within a game and this I got. Thumbs up Total War :)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 20, 2013
												Pros:+ Only TW to date that's in the gunpowder age+ Naval combat is exciting and yet to be topped by the titles after it+ Geographically the largest, and most diverse, TW game+ Unit variety (gunpowder, melee, cavalry, artillery, etc) makes land combat more intricate and strategic+ Introduced the tech tree+ Agents are now more useful and have more impact on the campaign mapCons:- Very poor release debut (almost as bad as Rome 2: Total War)- Naval combat does have some kinks- No real depth for Generals and no Family Tree- Dramatically limited modding compared to past titlesThe Bottom LineCreative Assembly took quite a risk with Empire: Total War.The franchise up to this point was firmly rooted in the melee combat eras of warfare and the concept of adapting the gameplay to anything after 15th century Europe seemed like an unappealing and potentially problematic idea.To a degree those reactions weren't quite baseless when the game finally released with an unhealthy amount of performance and technical issues but once those started to get hammered out and players started getting into the meat of the game the experience turned out to be quite enticing.As with all Total War games however the experience the player gets out of the game is highly reliant on whether or not the time period is personally appealing. Those who find the 18th century interesting will obviously find a lot to love here but those uninterested may move on fairly quickly.8 musketballs out of 10

content:
Posted: July 9, 2014
												I have played Total War games for years (The original Rome and Medieval all the way to the newest Rome) I always enjoy going back and starting a new campaign in Empire Total War. I won't lie, the AI can be a little frustrating. (Especially during diplomacy) Though they can be frustrating, the scale of the game and the heat of battle blow the AI's short commings out of the water. The feature of this game that excits me the most is the scale of the world. The world is divided into three theaters, the Americas, India, and Eurpope allowing you to engage in wars in three differant parts of the world at once (both on land and sea). I strongly recomend this game for anyone who is a fan of the franchise or is looking for a 1700's/1800's strategy game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 26, 2014
												Great game. I have played quite a lot of this game over the years and i have throughly enjoyed myself and still do, i always end up coming back to this game time and time again. The theatre system really helps to make your empire feel huge as it stretches several continents. The combat can get a bit boring at times when your troops just stand there exchanging fire but there is much more strategical depth to it then that. The variation of units isn't bad and with the DLC and mods there is a lot of unique units. I feel that this game has a lot of replayablity because every campaign is different and there are soo many different ways you can approach empire building, there is also a lot of depth into unit research which add new formations and equipment to you units which can change the way you play. This is one of my favorite games of all time, i definetly recommend this game if you have enjoyed any of the other total war games. But if you have played napoleon total war you might find some things lacking like having client states and less ship variation but having theatres really makes up for it in my opinion.

												Empire Total War is the best Total War game out there. In Shogun 2 and Rome 2 sure the graphics are better, but there is only one map in those games. I was able to conquer the world twice, that shows how much I love this game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 24, 2014
												This is now becoming an old game compaired to the latest and newest games in the Total War franchise but i still enjoy this game. I have playing this game for a long time and i still manage to enjoy its endless options on who to play as and what you want to do, i like to play sweden and take over the Americas and thats just one of the many options availbale. Now with the newer games like Shogun 2 and Napoleon (wasn't really a fan of Rome 2) this game has been outdone in graphics and more but i still like to come back to this game when i have spare time and ready up my army for a battle against the russian war machine or a naval battle against the french. This game by itself is fun but the most fun comes from mods, but there is one that is essential: http://www.moddb.com/mods/darthmod-empireThis is a game changing mod that opens up a wide and new expanise world to play in with larger amounts of troops, better graphics, new and improved sounds, gameplay and the ability to play as almost any faction that is not available in the normal game. This lets you play as minor nations like the knights of st. john and other minor factons, because of this ability to play as lesser factions opens up a new level of freedom the orignal game doesn't offer. The new A.I makes the game harder to play due to it being stronger and you the choice to start off weaker. This game is getting old compared to the new total war games but this is your game. with over +300 hours on it i still enjoy it, for only $20 i think it is worth picking up this game if you are looking for a good strategy war game set in the 18th century. I hope this helped influence your choice and this is just my opion of the game and should not be interprated as fact.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 27, 2014
												I was never a fan of the Total War series but the videos of all those ridiculously huge battles was always something I loved. After being tempted and pushed to try this title by one of my friends, I decided to sit down and give it a go. And I love it. Micromanaging an Empire, building up Units and conquering lands along with huge battles and drawn out sequences make this a tactician's wet dream. This is the first Total War game that I have ever played and sat down thoroughly with.I am not disappointed. On the other hand, I was informed by many that [Darthmod] improves the game substantially, so I have never truly experienced the "Vanilla" version of the game (one which is untouched by mods and 3rd party fixes). I love Darthmod and ETW, both compliment one another and with the whole new addition of extra units and better A.I. this really vamps up the game as a whole. See the end of the review for more links on where to download Darthmod.I do, however, admit that ETW does suffer from its fair share of bugs and broken game issues but do not let that detract you from buying this. It's a great title. I have purchased all the DLC for the game too and the extra units are *very* much worth it. Heck, even game changing! A great title, yet sometimes awkward to play due to strange A.I. behaviour and crashes due to... well, we all know that Total War games since Empire are buggy and unfixed.Overall score: 8/10 (it'd be a lot lower without the mods I've added :p)Darthmod v.8.0 on ModDB.I would highly suggest you download this mod via Torrent! It's a lot faster and easier to obtain, I find ModDB's speeds too slow. Be sure to seed back to atleast 90% for everyone else who wants the mod too!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 26, 2015
												I'm almost breaching playtime of 1000 hours. After all this time, Empire never fails me. It has had a buggy release, a bumpy start... but I've not played the same amount of time on any other Total War game. Why? Because Empire: Total War has an immense replayability, lots of factions, a great modding community with a large variety of mods, a whole century to play in and half the world as a map. It's a game you'll come back to. I know the Total War fanbase is often divided in those that favour melee like Medieval, Rome... and those that have a soft spot for the muskets. I'm with the latter, but give it a shot. It's a versatile game.Also, I'd like to recommend Napoleon: Total War, but where it excels in graphics and gameplay over Empire, it lacks replayability. I, for one, shall always return to Empire for a couple of extra hours of fun. Be it now, or in days or weeks, I'll play this game. To end, I'd like to underline the fact that the uniforms of this era are made to outfab the opponent. Yes, that's right, no plain, boring khakis for this man. I find the lack of fab in today's warfare... disturbing.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2015
												My favourite out of the total war series franchise so far that I have played, but thats just my opinion. It's quite in depth for the era it represents and the game is really enjoyable. I have spent many hours marching my empire towards victory, economically, logistically, militarily and politically. One moment I am a general leading my armies and the next I am a diplomat. Absolutely love this game :) I love the fact you can even personalise your regiments which is added fun.Some down sides are the unit cards could be improved, more locations and more option to customise your nation. Also the diplomacy could be a bit more in depth. Overall a very pleasant gaming experience and will continues to be.But for what it's worth and the price I paid for it I can't knock it and I would reccommend it. Hours of fun and joy thats what I look for within a game and this I got. Thumbs up Total War :)

But if you get good you will ignore these things. Although i dont think the game is worth it at 20.00$. Buy Napoleon Total War if you like multiplayer. Its 15.00$ With a bigger online community left thanks to Youtubers like robinhoodgaming, and a bit smaller but more detailed campaign map. Darthmod also works better on Napoleon Total War. But i will still reccomend this game to people who want a long term campaign, you can dominate The Early Americas, The Middle East, India, And of course Europe.

content:
Posted: December 14, 2013
												This is a good strategy game, but for those of you who've not played any total war games previously, I recommend playing the game on easy mode. This is because there are a lot of faction who are able to gang up on you.This game allows you to pick a faction and command their army. You can create a larger economy, and thus a bigger army to expand your operations.You are able to partake in diplomatic relations to create trade deals and allies. Alternatively, you can use this feature to bribe your way out of 'sticky' situations, or you can even use it to declare war on another faction.I would give this game a 7 and a half out of 10.The above score would be higher if there were not a few flaws within this game, such as the unbalanced auto-resolve feature, and a few other things I can't be bothered to remember.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 12, 2014
												It's different than other TW games, but it's a refreshing change. Guns don't make the game less exciting, as some argue; instead, they require a change of tactics. Playing in the colonial era can actually be quite fun. The graphics are an improvement, though they aren't great, but in this kind of game, I prefer gameplay over visuals. The gameplay is great - the world is gigantic, there is a new building system that makes building multiple structures simultaneously possible, there is a technology and philosophy research area, there are gentleman, naval battles where you can actually control your ships (I don't enjoy these much, though they look nice), there is North America and some of South America, and India (which we only got a glimpse of in Alexander!) There are many playable factions, and you can even unlock the American Indian factions by purchasing the Warpath DLC (this, again, requires a drastic change in strategy from the main ETW game, so buyer beware; it's probably also the only DLC worth buying, and only for a few bucks). Oh, and there's also the good ole US of A, which can be played in a campaign tracing the nation's development from a few settlers in Jamestown to an independent but vulnerable republic at the turn of the century. A few cons: the game is a bit glitchy, battles usually take place in boring forts that all look the same instead of cities, cannon have limitless ammo (could be a pro), game can get slow with the sheer number of factions at the end of every turn.The game came out very unfinished, but it's been polished up and is now defnitely worth buying for any TW fan.

content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
												Good game with a unique trading system. Campaign map gameplay feels smooth and easy, with enough micro- and macromanagement to keep you entertained for a while. Combat however, is often awkward with non-responsive or slow responding troops, and sieges are a downright pain at times. Darthmod is a must-have, since it fixes a lot of battles. Naval battles are fun and rewarding, although they tend to get too messy and clustered when fighting with a large fleet against an equally large fleet. All in all, the game has many new and unique options never seen in gaming before, and I'd recommend trying it out if you like strategy games.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 23, 2014
												This is definately the best of the ,,Total war´´-Games,playing in 18th and 19th century..It also beats its successor,which is playing in the napoleonic conflicts,as i would say..After playing more than 180 Hours for now,i can really recommend this game,as one of the best strategy-games,which are available at all..It's very dynamic in its battle-system,on land,or at sea,despite the fact,that the naval battles are sometimes a bit clumsy in the handling of the ships,but there are many types of weather and circumstances at sea battles,which are not just looking phenomenal,they are also taking influence in the ongoing of the battle..Such,you are in a great advantage,if the wind is blowing in the back at your sail for example,because you can start firing earlier, and you are also faster at all..But the Battles on Land are even the most impressive in that game,because they are providing a lot of opportunities mostly,by hiding units in forests,or just from distance to the enemy,if there's fog..The enemy is- And that's something which seems to be a very sheldom phenomene in Video games- Also able to gather tactical and strategical advantages,not just in superior manpower,but also in the experience and abilities of their Regiments and commanders. Also,the cavalry units of the enemy aren't just ordered into a wholeunit of pikemen,as they are now in Rome II..In Land battles,the infantry is,as in realisitc circumstances too,the Fundamental might of any army,providing the highest power,the most dynamic combat and abilities,and- of course-taking the most casaulties..As historical correctly (which is not the use in this game,as you can see as soon as the game starts,such as Sweden for example,is suddenly allied(!) with russia,during the time of the great nordic war,such as Great Britain can be played in 1700 (Founded in 1707) etc.), the Infantry regiments are mostly formed out of 160-200 Men,armed with muskets. The musket firing distance is also very realistic,and goes up to 70-100 meters at maximum,if fired by the line-infantry..Some units,armed with rifles,not with muskets,are useful by up to about 120 Meters in this game..Of course,any circumstances in battle are also taking influence onto the fighting spirit of the soldiers,which could also be enforced by elite units nearby,such as the general staff..Rainy weather causes Malfunctions of the muskets,because of an ineffectivity of gunpowder etc..It's a very time intensive,but then again,a great game,even despite the fact,it's not historically accurate at all.Depending on,which era you want to play in,i really recommend this game and its successor,which is ,,Napoleon:Total war´´.

content:
Posted: March 5, 2015
												Despite having major issues in the begining, crashing, bugs etc, I really enjoyed playing this game. Like the other Total War games it has a mix of a turn based campaign map where you build up your Cities, Towns, Infrastructure and strategicaly move your troops. Real-Time battles from Open Fields and Seiging Forts to Sea Battles with fleets of heavy first rate ships of the line.Still the game has issues but they can be looked past, because who doesn't love conquering enemy nations with several "stacks of doom".Pros :Game looks great on high graphics settings.Sound is Great.Great Ship battles with a veriety of ships.3 different Continents to conquer - Americas, Europe and India.Large open fields to fight on with large army's.Historical Battles.Able to save presets for troop selection (Multiplayer and custom battles).Different victory conditions.Multiplayer, though you don't really see any games on it any more (luckily all the achievments are soloable against the AI).Cons : Diplomacy needed alot more work, AI can be completely stupid when it comes to the negotiations asking for rediculas things.AI on open field battle needed a bit more work, but its not really noticable here when your having fun slaughtering them all lol.The battle results - Heroic victory etc displays wrong.Poorly Optimized for AMD Graphics cards because its sponsored by Nvidia.Kill 1 million enemies Achievment... ugh this is 1 boring grind, 400+ hours and I haven't hit 200k kills yet.My advice is to wait for when it's on sale but it's still too good of a game to wait for that :P

content:
Posted: December 31, 2014
												Empire quickly became my favorite strategy game over all.  I loved the details that went into the rendering of units, technologies and especially the accuracy of how those techs were used on the battle maps.  Naval combat is a particular love of mine.  I am a history major and love maritime history as well.  Being able to actually control the ships in line combat looks amazing,runs smoothly usually and is so much fun!If there is a real problem it is the AI.  Diplomacy makes no sense really when a nation like the Maratha Confederacywill declare war on England for no reason that I can see.  In battles sometime the AI will move troops for no reason, it makes the battles a lot easier at times but does loose a bit to the challenge factor. Over all Empire is my favorite game in the series and I hope everyone has a change to play.

content:

												"Wenn es funktioniert funktioniert es gut" hat jemand im Forum über dieses Spiel geschrieben und dem kann ich mich eigentlich nur anschließen. Das Spiel machte sehr lange sehr viel Spaß und steht seinen vorgängern in nichts nach. Die vielen Neuerungen, die es bei den Vorgängern (RomT W oder Medieval 2 TW) noch nicht gab sind nicht nur eine willkommene Abwechslung für alle Fans der Total War Reihe sondern sie machen das Spiel auch wesentlich anspruchsvoller und komplexer. Da fällt es dann kaum noch auf das ab und zu die Grafik beginnt zu flattern, einzelne Einheiten im Kampf an einer Wand hängenbleiben wodurch das gesammte Regiment nahezu handlungsunfähig wird oder der Kampf in zeitlupe schneller abläuft als mit normaler geschwindigkeit weil das spiel in dieser zu stark rukt (selbst auf PC´s die die Anforderungen übertreffen). Das einizige was den Spielspaß wirklich schmällert sind die Abstürze und teilweise nicht ladbare Speicherstände. Dennoch ein gelungenes Spiel.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 9, 2014
												8/10 The gambit paid off, Total War crew. I've been a Total War player since the original Medieval: Total War release in the early 2000's and this game definitely takes a few steps in the right direction. Changing the map and "territory" style, atmosphere of play to include things like trade turn-by-turn trade routs and political decisions that actually affect the game (more than just how other factions see you) and adding two of my favourite things: Ship fights and technology trees! The ability to diversify your faction as you see fit is what makes this RTS so groundbreaking, and it does not at all lose the original appeal, which is killing massive amounts of your foes, on the battlefield. The different combat style of firearms as a primary means of murder is the obvious difference from any other Total War game I've yet to play, and it first the concept daunted me - I am a fan of my melee mashes, but after many, many playthroughs as various factions and on different difficulty settings, I can calmly say that this was the absolute breakthrough for the Total War franchise. If you're on the fence about RTSs or are even just a casual gamer, this title has a difficulty setting just for you, and if you're an RTS junkie you can crank up the battles and the campaign (hapiness of your people, who declares war upon whom, difficulty to make aggreements with other factions) difficulties independent of each other. This is great because if you're crap at battles, you can keep those easy while you make your foes all the more bloodthirsty and unforgiving, as well as the inverse, if you're a master tactician.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 9, 2014
												It's hard to recommend this title simply because for 80% of what it does, you can find better elsewhere (for example Europa Universalis).The pitfalls: Campaign is rather linear due to the pre-existing diplomatic relations for each nation and the fact that almost all of them are already established empires. (Prussia is the most notable exception)You can only play as the major nations.Sometimes the Total War turn-based system can be a bit merciless for misclicks.As in all Total War games, there is little punishment for rapid expansion except for in diplomacy, which ultimately ends up being a small factor.The merits: The tech tree is nonlinear, allowing for your nation to develop in semi-unique fashion. You can focus on infantry, cavalry, artillery, navy, metalworking, farming, social equality, education, etc individually. Also, the advances you make are actually felt during war or peace (depending on the tech) so it actually feels like you are doing something meaningful.The government management can be fairly nice. Some have mentioned that you don't have as much of a personal attachment to idividual leaders as in past games, but to be fair, this isn't an rpg, and it isn't a game about world leaders. This game is focussed on the civ as a whole, but the quality of the leaders does make an impact on how your nation runs. It's a pretty good balance, imo. The special agents (rake and gentleman) have multiple functions for different playstyles. Also, you don't need to worry about manually sending diplomats to other nations. You can just talk to them.The namesake of the franchise is, however, where the game shines brightest. The warfare is engaging, meaningful, and intuitive. Strong armies are more likely to win, but with good control and leadership, a smaller force can win. It isn't up to chance either (unless you autorun battles, which you shouldn't do for important ones anyways).Since you have direct control of your forces, you don't need to worry about combat being unfair in any way, and you get to see what happens and why in the battles.This brings me to the battles: They are great. The units follow your orders in an organized manner, only stalling if you try to rush them across tough terrain and the like. The battlegrounds often give you strategic defensive points and the like such as hills, walls, even garrisonable buildings. Different ammunition, formations, and weapons are available as you advance in tech, giving you more satisfaction from research as you see your troops perform better and differently. Also, the generals aren't nearly as overpowered as in other Total War titles. They are mortal here, so you can't charge them into the enemy army alone and expect great things, and that just makes sense.

content:
Posted: June 12, 2014
												It's different than other TW games, but it's a refreshing change. Guns don't make the game less exciting, as some argue; instead, they require a change of tactics. Playing in the colonial era can actually be quite fun. The graphics are an improvement, though they aren't great, but in this kind of game, I prefer gameplay over visuals. The gameplay is great - the world is gigantic, there is a new building system that makes building multiple structures simultaneously possible, there is a technology and philosophy research area, there are gentleman, naval battles where you can actually control your ships (I don't enjoy these much, though they look nice), there is North America and some of South America, and India (which we only got a glimpse of in Alexander!) There are many playable factions, and you can even unlock the American Indian factions by purchasing the Warpath DLC (this, again, requires a drastic change in strategy from the main ETW game, so buyer beware; it's probably also the only DLC worth buying, and only for a few bucks). Oh, and there's also the good ole US of A, which can be played in a campaign tracing the nation's development from a few settlers in Jamestown to an independent but vulnerable republic at the turn of the century. A few cons: the game is a bit glitchy, battles usually take place in boring forts that all look the same instead of cities, cannon have limitless ammo (could be a pro), game can get slow with the sheer number of factions at the end of every turn.The game came out very unfinished, but it's been polished up and is now defnitely worth buying for any TW fan.

content:
Posted: December 14, 2013
												This is a good strategy game, but for those of you who've not played any total war games previously, I recommend playing the game on easy mode. This is because there are a lot of faction who are able to gang up on you.This game allows you to pick a faction and command their army. You can create a larger economy, and thus a bigger army to expand your operations.You are able to partake in diplomatic relations to create trade deals and allies. Alternatively, you can use this feature to bribe your way out of 'sticky' situations, or you can even use it to declare war on another faction.I would give this game a 7 and a half out of 10.The above score would be higher if there were not a few flaws within this game, such as the unbalanced auto-resolve feature, and a few other things I can't be bothered to remember.

content:
Posted: September 30, 2014
												Play with Darthmod Found on Total War centre (I can not recommend you not play without it as the game lacks all flavor), In the game you Create armies, diplomacy is involved and you require to manage your economy as well as political ambitions. Trade is also a factor especially in the eastern trading company in the age of exploration and Colonisitation.Generally speaking European factions have a lot more and slightly expensive guns and line infantry effective at range, poorer in hand to hand combat as the bulk of their forces as well as have to compete agaist other european powers. Compared to that of indian/middle eastern troops that have lower morale but elephants, camels and swordsmen which use more hit and run tactics with larger amies similar to native Americans that can close the gap and defeat european armies which are more costly.  There are also Spys (rakes) and Technology involves (gentlemen) who can steal, assasinate and sabotage targetsGenerals in your armies, and spies/rakes gain traits as they do more actions, Traits give permenent bonuses or negative atributes and some are quite funny like a mistress. You also have to watch how much industry you build because it effects the population and they may rebel as well as relion being involved taking a provience of another faith requires management and larger garrisons initially to make them submit and conform to your empire.Without getting to much involved there is a lot of detail in this game and I highly recommend this as probally the best total war game arguably.

content:
Posted: February 26, 2014
												Great game. I have played quite a lot of this game over the years and i have throughly enjoyed myself and still do, i always end up coming back to this game time and time again. The theatre system really helps to make your empire feel huge as it stretches several continents. The combat can get a bit boring at times when your troops just stand there exchanging fire but there is much more strategical depth to it then that. The variation of units isn't bad and with the DLC and mods there is a lot of unique units. I feel that this game has a lot of replayablity because every campaign is different and there are soo many different ways you can approach empire building, there is also a lot of depth into unit research which add new formations and equipment to you units which can change the way you play. This is one of my favorite games of all time, i definetly recommend this game if you have enjoyed any of the other total war games. But if you have played napoleon total war you might find some things lacking like having client states and less ship variation but having theatres really makes up for it in my opinion.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 7, 2016
												Empire total war is like a sickly child (no offence to anyone who might have one). Of course, it's your baby and you love it, but it's just not... there, you know?Empire, even to this day, lacks polish (not the country, dangit) and there are still some absolutely ridiculous undertakings by the AI, most of which we'll get to later. But how about the pros and cons of the Vanilla game, shall we? PROS-excellent representation of 18th century warfare-the emergence of nations, such as Greece, USA and Scotland (among others) is interesting and mixes the campaign up-you may now contest in 3 theatres: America, India and Europe-The campaign map is pretty, has lots of cool features such as towns that magically spring out of the ground, and a realistic intercept feature, meaning you can't just trot by an enemy army without implications-Graphics are still ok, despite it's age-Naval battles are a very welcome introduction, and they're pulled of qute well.-Interesting tech tree-Fantastic new trading system on the campaign mapCONS-Battle AI can be gamebreaking-AI diplomacy is all over the place-Melee combat is an absolute snoozefest, and infantry charging is all sorts of broken, glitchy and weird-18th century warfare means little in unique units within the same culture. All european armies will end up looking the same, just as all native american armies are just as similar-With so much emphasis on the navy and trade, naval battles can become very frequent and very repetitive, especially in local trade theatres and against pirates-Autoresolving is broken. You can have a 1500 army come up against 80 rebel swordmen and lose 300 men. How?If you do get this game, i highly recommend DarthMod. I'm not gonna bother with the links etc. but it's definately worth a look see. The battles in Empire are underwhelming, especially with the poor AI, decision making and lack of bloodthirsty action, but DarthMod does a great job at reparing a few glaring problems as well as adding new features not only to battles, but the campaign as well. The broken AI means i give this game an overall 6/10. The campaign map is the best it's ever been, but in battle, it's lackluster. With DarthMod however, this bumbs it up to 8/10 level. Makes battles and campaign far more engaging.

content:
Posted: July 9, 2014
												I have played Total War games for years (The original Rome and Medieval all the way to the newest Rome) I always enjoy going back and starting a new campaign in Empire Total War. I won't lie, the AI can be a little frustrating. (Especially during diplomacy) Though they can be frustrating, the scale of the game and the heat of battle blow the AI's short commings out of the water. The feature of this game that excits me the most is the scale of the world. The world is divided into three theaters, the Americas, India, and Eurpope allowing you to engage in wars in three differant parts of the world at once (both on land and sea). I strongly recomend this game for anyone who is a fan of the franchise or is looking for a 1700's/1800's strategy game.

												The game offers a substantial amount of content, however the product is in all ways underwhelming. It is quite obvious that the game had much more potential that was left uncapitalized on. Having played both Empire and Napoleon Total War, it is apparent that Empire would have, could have, and should have had the overall polish and refinement of battlefield controls that were found in Napoleon. As a whole, both games are rather enjoyable, however I would suggest Napoleon Total War instead, for fans who are significantly more interested in the battlefield experience.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 21, 2014
												This has become my favorite Total War game. No doubt it has many flaws (the least of which are technical issues, which really hamper the game at times). But IMO, with the correct Mods (i.e. Darthmod) this game is the largest in scope and really gives you the sense of controlling a world wide empire.  What makes this game so enjoyable for me is the incredible amount of variance in play throughs. Your campaign as Great Britain or The United Provinces, which sees a lot of overseas expansion, is likely going to be very different than a campaign as Austria or one of the Indian factions, which are much more land locked.  Of course, you can always mix it up and change history by taking over Europe as the Ottoman Empire, then invade and conquer the Americas. The actual battles are great as well, and again with the right mods they can actually be a challenge. t is very fun to assault an enemy position or to use the terrain to make a strong defensive position and repel enemy attacks.  I think the graphics and animations during battles are superb, even if more recent titles like Shogun 2 have improvements. As I mentioned this is my favorite Total War game, and will likely remain so as Rome 2 is a mess and I just can't bring myself to play it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 8, 2016
												After playing this game for a few hours I rate it as one the the greatest real time strategy games of all time. Equally fun if you take a hands off approach to your battles and rely on the auto resolve funstion or take control against insermountable odds and use keen strategic placement of your troups along will real time battle manuevers to outflank and crush your foes. Varying nations have different bonuses and starting situations. A multitude of possible alliances and backstabs are possible and achieveable by various means. Placate your population with religion, sorted diversions or military presence or victories. Utilize the same to dominate a conquered populace and/or turn them in time to your loyal followers. Infiltrate opposing countries with spies, assasinate or sabatoge as you go. Send out religious emisaries to turn populations to the one true religion. Train researchers to bolster your war technology or steal/trade it from another country.  The Grand Campaign is amongst the best offered in any strategy game and was probably the best at the time the game was released. So many factions to conquer. So many alternative routes to take to world domination. Replayability is off the charts.

content:
Posted: August 28, 2016
												Empire total war was the first game I played in the total war series. It was a good step I don't regret.Buy this game and it's DLC's on sale and you will be very impressed. If perhaps giving you a few over powered units (ahem, America goes from a milita to op army) The campaign is either a play through of the birth of the US, the leading of the major tribes in North America against colonial powers, or attempting to conquer the world as an empire as your choice.The game is a solid build with my cheap computer able to handle it well. Upgrading your pc will only upgrade your experience. modding is strong in the community. Many hours of your life will be rewarded with your armies marching through out the old and new world. There are a few glitches here and there that come with a game trying to manage a few thousand troops moving around but nothing game breaking or rage inducing. A splendid way to enter the world of Total War. 9.5/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 12, 2011
												I really spent so many hours playing Empire: Total War because of the much more realistic economy system than any other Total War Game before (and that's what mostly really mattered between 1700 and 1800).Not only with colonization you have many options for trade with expensive goods (like coffee, tea, sugar and many more) with other colonist nations, you also can try to push up or down the price on the world market to enhance your situation.You also have minor cities with different prosperity levels besides your provincial capitals where you can focus on factories or (if it is a poor city) on churches to improve religious integrity or even brothels for a satisfied population. You may also build Universities to research technologies faster to get a positive distance to your neighbour states.All in all, Empire: Total War is a really good game and today you get it definately for 10€ or below (at least in bundles). I can recommend it to everybody who likes games that combine epic real time battles with realistic turn-based management on a campaign map!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 28, 2014
												I absolutely love this game, who would not want to take over the Americas? who would not want to watch Russia take over India? who would not want to help the maratha confederacy take over the world? Who would not want to have the chance to kill some Frence? Who would not want the chance to make trade partners for Britain? So many possibilities, it is a endless game that no one can say is boring, i loved this game more than i liked shogun 2 and napoleon total war put together ( probally because i do not like those ones ). An example of how good this game is: When i was Austria i thought expanding into the ottoman empire would be the best possibility. However i needed to expand into Germany a little first to secure my poistion. When i invaded Prussia my good friend poland- lithuania went to the aid of the Prussians and declared war on me, I did not want to take their lands however so i soon amde a peace treaty with them. Once i had taken the settlement i wanted i tried to make peace with the Prussians, they did refuse so i was forced to continue my war. However i soon realized they was not going to go through the poland - lithuania territory to get me, so i moved further into Germany territory. but soon i was stabbed in the back by the polish ( just they do now to us English ) I was forced to raise more armies to deal with tem, this caused tention between me and my western allies.  Once poland- lithuania was mine i had to invade my allies, this made more friction between me and Britain, my second best friend. Then before i got the chance to Invade the Ottoman empire ( my original plan ) The spanish declared that my monarch was not the true blood to my throne ( my kind had died leaving a Queen in charge of a country - Oh no! ) I soon invaded alsace and lorraine and paris. once they were mine i payed for a peace treaty with Spain, due to them being widespread i didn't want to wait to build strong navies. By this point Britain was nervous of my power and did not like me, even though they were still my allies. And the ottoman empire i wanted to invade loved me completely. This shows just how much the game can change over the time you play, adding to the complexity of the whole game. I know that during my European wars Britain was taking over the thirteen colonies and at war with france and spain. This made Britain more of a threat to me, since they now had a average sized amount of land in the Americas, and nce they fell in Erope i would have another potential threat over in the Americas. The guns also are brilliant to use! I often just make a army of cheap line infantry just so i can let the enemy come towards me, their cavelry always dies shortly after. My cannons ( 1 to 2 units ) always lower enemy moral before they get into my range of fire for my infantry. Then the cavelry ( 1 to 2 units ) always cover the flanks and kill the runaways at the end of the battle. Over all i can say that i really recomend this game and that anyone who does not agree that this is a brilliant game should go back to it and reconsider their choice. Sorry about this being a overly long review by the way, i hope that no one has gotten bored reading it. for anyone wanting to know more of these battle stories please join my group, t is dedicated to the total war series, we have player of the week and regular announcements and discussions. the discussions are about which faction we use in what games and more while the announcements are for planning a multiplayer campaign in advance. I believe that anyone interested in the total war series should join my group, 17 members currently ( 28 / 2 / 14 ). Yours SincerlyGiaus Julius Ceasar

This shows just how much the game can change over the time you play, adding to the complexity of the whole game. I know that during my European wars Britain was taking over the thirteen colonies and at war with france and spain. This made Britain more of a threat to me, since they now had a average sized amount of land in the Americas, and nce they fell in Erope i would have another potential threat over in the Americas. The guns also are brilliant to use! I often just make a army of cheap line infantry just so i can let the enemy come towards me, their cavelry always dies shortly after. My cannons ( 1 to 2 units ) always lower enemy moral before they get into my range of fire for my infantry. Then the cavelry ( 1 to 2 units ) always cover the flanks and kill the runaways at the end of the battle. Over all i can say that i really recomend this game and that anyone who does not agree that this is a brilliant game should go back to it and reconsider their choice. Sorry about this being a overly long review by the way, i hope that no one has gotten bored reading it. for anyone wanting to know more of these battle stories please join my group, t is dedicated to the total war series, we have player of the week and regular announcements and discussions. the discussions are about which faction we use in what games and more while the announcements are for planning a multiplayer campaign in advance. I believe that anyone interested in the total war series should join my group, 17 members currently ( 28 / 2 / 14 ). Yours SincerlyGiaus Julius Ceasar

content:
Posted: May 12, 2011
												I really spent so many hours playing Empire: Total War because of the much more realistic economy system than any other Total War Game before (and that's what mostly really mattered between 1700 and 1800).Not only with colonization you have many options for trade with expensive goods (like coffee, tea, sugar and many more) with other colonist nations, you also can try to push up or down the price on the world market to enhance your situation.You also have minor cities with different prosperity levels besides your provincial capitals where you can focus on factories or (if it is a poor city) on churches to improve religious integrity or even brothels for a satisfied population. You may also build Universities to research technologies faster to get a positive distance to your neighbour states.All in all, Empire: Total War is a really good game and today you get it definately for 10€ or below (at least in bundles). I can recommend it to everybody who likes games that combine epic real time battles with realistic turn-based management on a campaign map!

content:
Posted: August 28, 2016
												Empire total war was the first game I played in the total war series. It was a good step I don't regret.Buy this game and it's DLC's on sale and you will be very impressed. If perhaps giving you a few over powered units (ahem, America goes from a milita to op army) The campaign is either a play through of the birth of the US, the leading of the major tribes in North America against colonial powers, or attempting to conquer the world as an empire as your choice.The game is a solid build with my cheap computer able to handle it well. Upgrading your pc will only upgrade your experience. modding is strong in the community. Many hours of your life will be rewarded with your armies marching through out the old and new world. There are a few glitches here and there that come with a game trying to manage a few thousand troops moving around but nothing game breaking or rage inducing. A splendid way to enter the world of Total War. 9.5/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1, 2014
												Total War's first foray into an age other than one of swords and bows, Empire, like much of this franchise, is a flawed gem. Being their first real go with armies that predominatly use guns, the AI work is sloppy and it really shows. It's pathetic how easy it is to expoit the AI's failings in battle and win yourself crushing victories that you shouldn't have gotten. It's also the first shot at naval combat, which functionally works better but still seems to generate complaints. Personally I blame that on a lack of knowledge about how to use warships in the age of sail in a fight more than anything else (hint: cut the enemy's battle line). Lastly, the diplomatic AI has a rather predictable habit of delivering you unpredictable war declarations. For example I was minding my own business as the French carving up North America for myself when I got war declared on me by the Marathas (India). Before too long they were landing armies in the Carribean and harassing my trade fleets. Why? I still have no idea, but it sure didn't help them when I dropped my huge armies fresh from American conquest into India. But damn was that war annoying when it started.So what's the good? The map is -huge-, and the number of choices for nations to play is considerable (Though most are European). In other words... replay value is in abundance here. And that's really all it needs, to be honest. A game like this is made for being replayed and ending up in various differing situations. And it is here that this game shines. Otherwise it's a mixed bag.What i'm trying to say is that this game is pretty decent, but you might not want this to be the first game in the series you try. It might sour your opinion and lead you to not looking into the other, arguably better or at least less flawed, entries into the series. But, this does have huge replay value. You will get alot of playtime out of this. If that's what you are looking for, then that might be all you need to have the pros of this game outweigh its problems.

content:
Posted: October 26, 2015
												If you've never played a Total War game, don't start with this one.Total War has always consisted of two parts: the turn-based overland map, and the real-time battles, and I'll adress each separately:Overland Map: Unlike every other Total War game, there isn't one overland map, but several.  This game covers the globe, and has the most complex turn-based portion of any Total War game, with the most details.  The complexity approaches that of a dedicated strategy game, but the Total War style does not lend itself well to that level of complexity, and it can be quite overwhelming for those who don't want to micro-manage their empire. RTS Battles: How much you like the real time battles depends on how much you like the units involved.  If you're a fan of muskets and cannons, this is game delivers in spades.  If not, then this game isn't for you.  The artillery/gunpowder based battles play out differently than other Total War games, and for those who want more of the same, you should probably play a different game.To sum up: if you don't want artillery/gunpowder based battles, you should play a different Total War game.  If you want artillery/gunpowder based battles, but you don't want a complex overworld map, play Napoleon Total War instead.  If you want a complex overworld map, but aren't particularly interested in the battles, get a different strategy game (such as Europa Universalis or Civilization).  But if you want great artillery based battles and a (overly-) complex overworld, this is the game for you.
